story:
All,

As you know, Jen has been battling Stage 3 melanoma cancer since May of last year. The last 18 months have been filled with surgeries, hospital stays, MRI/CT/PET scans, and an entire year of chemotherapy. Through all of that, many of you have blessed our family in multiple ways. You have prayed for us. You have encouraged us. You have brought meals to us. You have kept us laughing and smiling, even in the midst of all the suffering cancer brings. We are beyond grateful.

So, it is with a fair amount of trepidation that we even make this next request. Cancer is expensive, and it has finally caught up with us in the last few months. Jen's specific chemotherapy treatment alone runs us almost $1000 every month. Regular doctor visits, biopsies, scans, and other expenses add up on top of that. 

Let me be clear. We will be able to eventually pay these bills. We've been adjusting as a family throughout the year (postponing vacations, cutting expenses, etc…), and we'll continue to do so. But, there are a few reasons we've decided to reach out. First, Jen's chemotherapy treatment finishes August 1st, and she'll begin the long process of recovering her strength (physical, mental, and emotional) while also weaning herself off high doses of pain medication. Reducing these medical expenses will go a long way toward eliminating one less thing for her to worry about. Second, and I know this may sound crazy, but we are excited to begin fostering children again. We've had to take a break for obvious reasons, and we don't feel comfortable resuming foster care until we've reduced these bills. Finally, many of you have asked for ways you can continue to help our family beyond prayers, meals, and encouragement. We've done our best to keep finances out of the picture, but they are unfortunately very real and continue to mount. They are a definite need, and if helping financially is something you feel led to, we want to make that an option.

So, if you would like to contribute, we would be extremely grateful. In fact, we have a special T-shirt for anyone donating $25 or more as a way to celebrate Jen's chemotherapy coming to an end. The amazingly talented Brian Brasher kindly created two amazing designs for you to choose from, and we'd be stoked to see everyone rocking these shirts. In typical Jen fashion, she has decided to ride the 100 mile LiveStrong challenge at the end of October to celebrate. We've created a LiveStrong team named Derailing Cancer (haha, cycling joke), so the T-shirt designs reflect that idea.

We're going to run this campaign all the way up to Jen's final CT/PET scans on October 3rd. That's when we'll hopefully hear the doctor say "No Evidence of Disease." That will be a big day, and it seems fitting to end on such a big day.

To wrap things up, I just want to say how much everyone's support over the last 18 months has meant to me and our family. We could not have done this without the love and support of so many family and friends. The majority of patients don't continue the full year on this chemotherapy treatment because it's so difficult, but Jen will soon be done with the entire year. You have all helped make that possible. Whether you can donate or not, know that we treasure your friendship more than these words can say. Thank you so much.

Sincerely,

Adam and Jen

story:
Short Summary 

New Britain is a lower income area, where many people do not have the availability to relax and de-stress during their day. With this funding, the class can stay a donation based class and those without means will be paid for. The rental of the space, and the buying of supplies (mats, blocks, cleaner, music, maintenance, etc), is what the money is going towards.

My name is Jessica Hart. I have completed my 200-hr certification in Hatha and Vinyasa Yoga. I have taught different styles of classes and am trying to make a more affordable version of Yoga in the inner city area.

In a normal setting, a yoga class can cost 10-15 dollars per class. Not everyone has the ability to attend, due to that reason alone. The area of New Britain is half college town, half lower income housing. In either case, these individuals cannot afford to spend that kind of money multiple times a week, for an hour to themselves. 

With your contribution, these individual will be able to:

~come to the classes multiple times per week for free 

~be provided with a good quality mat at every practice

~have props to modify positions for any body type

~ have a safe, clean environment to practice in

 

What We Need 

 

Brake down of funding:

~One cheap mat can range between 15 and 30 dollars, a good mat can range between 60 and 130 dollars- we are aming for a higher quality mat (I am hoping to buy between 7 an 12)

~The space will cost roughly 100 dollars a week to rent,(4 to 5 classes per week) and the program will be ongoing

~Props, including but not limited to blocks, straps, blankets, eye pillows, bolsters, etc. This will be the most pricey of all the categories

~Advertising supplies- flyers, buisness cards, updated website

~Maintenance supplys to clean the mat, and the room, range from 100 to 200 dollars.

The Impact

I am trying to change peoples minds about yoga. I am trying to get it to everyone, no matter their financial means. Please donate what you can.

Other Ways You Can Help

Donate supplies- if you have lightly used mats, blocks, props, etc. Please e-mail me to let me know!

Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about your campaign.

Use the Indiegogo share tools!

story: My Grandson Alexander had a traumatic entrance into this world on June 19th. His oxygen was cut off during labor causing what the doctors say to be extensive brain damage. My daughter lives 900 miles away from me and I need to raise money to rent a car and pay for travel expenses to be with her and my grandson through this difficult time.
story_txt: My Grandson Alexander had a traumatic entrance into this world on June 19th. His oxygen was cut off during labor causing what the doctors say to be extensive brain damage. My daughter lives 900 miles away from me and I need to raise money to rent a car and pay for travel expenses to be with her and my grandson through this difficult time.

story:
Short Summary

Hi! My name is Shelley Jain and I am a freshman at Brooklyn College and a student in the 8-year-BA/MD Program. As a pre-health student, I am broadening my horizons by exploring health and healthcare around the world. 

This January, I will have the opportunity to volunteer and learn in Jamkhed, Maharashtra, India at the world-renowned Comprehensive Rural Health Project (CRHP), a leading institution in the primary health care movement that trains physicians, nurses, public health workers and local rural health workers; travel to rural villages to observe the daily work of village health workers; and accompany the CRHP mobile team of Ayurvedic physicians, nurses, social workers and development specialists on routine visits to rural areas. Participants will also and meet and engage with women health workers and hear personal stories of their life-transitions from teenage brides to respected health practitioners and political leaders. This four-week program introduces students to India through the study of international health and social anthropology.

What We Need & What You Get

The cost of the trip is over $3000 and I would appreciate any contribution that would bring me one step closer to reaching my goal. As an aspiring physician, I know that this trip will help me learn a lot and be an eye-opening experience.

The Impact

As a student and future doctor, I will gain the valuable skills of immersing myself in a completely new environment, communication, and medicine as I work with village health workers and trained physicians to improve health conditions and sustain low mortality rates with the Comprehensive Rural Health Project.
story_txt:
Short Summary
Hi! My name is Shelley Jain and I am a freshman at Brooklyn College and a student in the 8-year-BA/MD Program. As a pre-health student, I am broadening my horizons by exploring health and healthcare around the world. 
This January, I will have the opportunity to volunteer and learn in Jamkhed, Maharashtra, India at the world-renowned Comprehensive Rural Health Project (CRHP), a leading institution in the primary health care movement that trains physicians, nurses, public health workers and local rural health workers; travel to rural villages to observe the daily work of village health workers; and accompany the CRHP mobile team of Ayurvedic physicians, nurses, social workers and development specialists on routine visits to rural areas. Participants will also and meet and engage with women health workers and hear personal stories of their life-transitions from teenage brides to respected health practitioners and political leaders. This four-week program introduces students to India through the study of international health and social anthropology.


What We Need & What You Get
The cost of the trip is over $3000 and I would appreciate any contribution that would bring me one step closer to reaching my goal. As an aspiring physician, I know that this trip will help me learn a lot and be an eye-opening experience.


The Impact
As a student and future doctor, I will gain the valuable skills of immersing myself in a completely new environment, communication, and medicine as I work with village health workers and trained physicians to improve health conditions and sustain low mortality rates with the Comprehensive Rural Health Project.

story:
DEVELOP IMPROVED CORE FUNCTION WITH COREPRO

Is your core prepared to endure your active life?   Be better at what you love to do by training your core to engage more effectively during more activities with CorePro!

IS COREPRO FOR ME?

Whether you’re hooked on endurance sports, functional fitness or golf, CorePro can help supplement your training to improve your mobility, stability, and power for better results.  Stuck sitting more than you want to be? CorePro can help with posture to minimize the negative impact.

WHAT THE PROS THINK

 

WHY TRY COREPRO?

CorePro has multiple design and utility patents.  This means it’s uniquely different from any other product on the market today.  CorePro gets your body doing the work. Traditional wraparound back support products and weight belts do the support work for you. Our patented sleeve and elastic design is intended to help you engage your core muscles - a major support and stabilizing system for your spine.

 

WHAT CONSUMERS THINK

 

DO MORE WITH COREPRO  

 

TRAIN YOUR CORE FOR PROPER FORM

CorePro aids in cueing your abdominal wall without restricting spinal motion.  It prompts you to maintain and control your spine position throughout activities by activating your deep abdominal muscles. Good mobility comes from first establishing good stability.

CorePro aids in spinal stability by providing continual feedback to the abdominal wall to stay actively engaged while the body is in motion. It’s like a manual cue that does not get in the way of movement at full speed. CorePro can be used as a training aid for activation of the core and removed once you’ve mastered the technique of engaging the proper muscles.

Training transfer of power from lower to upper body (or the reverse) requires correct timing and function of the core. CorePro provides the body feedback to activate the core without limitations.  Ideal for golf, tennis, baseball and other rotational sports.

Improve your consistency throughout 18 holes and maintain full range of motion.

 

HOW COREPRO WORKS

CorePro activates your core by triggering your abdominal muscles to engage to help stabilize your spine.

How does activation happen?  The elastic straps pull across your stomach from opposite sides and provide gentle resistance to which prompts activation of your core muscles.

 

Our patented design works with the natural anatomy and physiology of your body, allows you to maintain full range of motion and helps to stabilize your spine to keep you moving.

CorePro is made of three key components:   

1. Breathable fabric sleeve made of a 4-way stretch material to provide both gentle compression and flexibility.

2. A soft, non-stretch back panel that provides an anchor for the elastic straps, in the same way your spine connects to your deep abdominal muscles.

 3. Four elastic straps that pull across your mid-section from opposite sides to offer gentle resistance and activation for your core muscles.

 

Full range of motion - your body does the work in a healthy way.

 

CorePro is slim enough to fit under clothing so you can wear it anywhere you go!

 

And you can even toss is in the washer!

 

 

 

PURCHASE A COREPRO NOW

 

WHAT WE NEED

We need your help to bring CorePro to the people who need it most!  We have spent over two years developing the product and produced small quantities to demonstrate it is ready for production.  Reaching our goal of $25,000 USD will enable us to source materials, hit our manufacturing minimums and ship the product directly to you.  

Stretch Goal - Additional Color

We’d love to offer CorePro in a neutral color so it’s even less visible under white clothing.  To achieve this we need to raise at least $100,000. When we reach our stretch goal the color option will be available with your size choice in the fulfillment survey sent at the end of the campaign.

PRODUCT TIMELINE  

 

MADE IN THE USA 

CorePro is 100% Made in the USA.  We source and sew everything domestically so we can be hands on throughout the process and to ensure the best quality for our customers.

Product Specifications & Details

  • Made in the USA
  • Machine Washable
  • Material Specifications 
    • Sleeve: 55% nylon, 33% cotton, 12% spandex
    • Trim: 97% cotton, 3% spandex
    • Elastic: 64% poly, 36% rubber
  • Medical Disclaimer: Content is for information purposes only, is not medical advice, and should not replace the recommendations of your healthcare provider. Consult your physician before use.

​

SPREAD THE WORD 

Not sure you need a CorePro but think it sounds interesting?  Please help us spread the word to your friends and family.  80% of Americans will experience back pain at some point in their lives, so you probably know someone who has suffered.  Please let them know about this new solution - it could make a big difference!  Share this link or hit us up on social @GetCorePro on Facebook, Instagram, and Twitter.  We really appreciate it!

 

WHO WE ARE

Hi, we're Gia and Kristen; college classmates from Princeton University who partnered to bring this powerful product to market.  Gia is the product mastermind.  She invented, designed and patented CorePro based on her extensive experience as physical therapist and athlete.  Kristen brings sales and marketing business expertise to the mix.  Together, we’re working to produce smart, well-designed products that will improve lives.  We know CorePro can make a difference for people suffering from back and posture issues and we want to get it into their hands as soon as possible.

Dr. Gia Fruscione holds both a physical therapy and massage therapy license. She received her undergraduate degree from Princeton University and her Doctor of Physical Therapy degree from the Feinberg School of Medicine at Northwestern University. Gia's continuing education portfolio is extensive and includes, but is not limited to: corrective exercise, suspension exercise, pilates, functional movement assessment tools, kinesiology taping, sports massage, myofascial release, and trigger point techniques. Gia is also Certified by the Titelist Performance Institute. During the summer of 2016, she spent time mentoring for rotational training with Jason Glass in Vancouver, BC, and with XPE Sports/CORE Institute in Boca Raton, FL implementing recovery bodywork techniques with a number of NFL and NHL athletes. Gia draws significantly from her history as a two-sport Division-I athlete at Princeton University and athlete with USA Field Hockey.

Kristen Leone has led teams in marketing, sales, and strategy at both startups and major corporations including: The Weather Company (an IBM Business), JOOR, WebMD, General Mills, Pfizer, and Arrowsight.  Kristen received an MBA from The Wharton School at the University of Pennsylvania and a BA from Princeton University.

FAQs

  • How Does Sizing Work?
    • Once the campaign closes, we will send a survey to all supporters to select their preferred CorePro sizes
    • CorePro is a unisex product that fits both men and women based on a measurement taken around your belly button.
    • CorePro comes in 7 sizes that fit waists that range in size from 25 inches - 47 inches (measured around your belly button)
  • What if CorePro doesn’t have my size?
    • Currently CorePro accommodates individuals who measure 25" - 47" around their trunk at the height of the belly button.
    • We recognize that this may limit our ability to serve everyone and we greatly appreciate your understanding in our inability to accommodate everyone at this time.
  • How can CorePro help with my posture?
    • It can help to cue better posture and activation of abdominal muscles when they are usually dormant (slouching at the desk), especially if you are sitting for extended periods of time.
    • When sitting upright, your body needs to use your abdominal wall to keep you in a good position.  CorePro is a physical reminder not to slouch as well as an active trigger for your core muscles to maintain proper position.
  • Will CorePro mask back pain?
    • It will not mask pain. It's not rigid, and therefore doesn’t limit/block movement. If pain is from movement, this will not restrict movement. If you are experiencing pain, please remember to consult your medical provider
  • Is the goal to help me move through pain?
    • No. The goal is to re-educate/activate your deep abdominal wall (some of the main stabilizing muscles for your spine). Many people have lost the ability to activate these muscles for stabilization and/or they have an inadequate endurance of these muscles. When the spine is not well stabilized it can cause pain.
  • Should I wear it even if I don’t have back pain or back issues?
    • If you don’t have trouble with your back, but know you have a core weakness then it can help and be proactive in avoiding possible back issues. Core weakness can be from poor fitness, pregnancy, abdominal surgery, hours at a desk, etc.
  • Will CorePro give me 6-pack abs?
    • Unfortunately, no.  :(
    • CorePro is designed to engage your deep abdominal stabilizing muscles under your rectus abdominis (commonly known as 6-pack).

RISKS & CHALLENGES

Very limited risk.  We have already established manufacturers and suppliers and produced the product in small batches.  The only potential issue could be a delay in production timing due to volume of orders (if we exceed our goal and need to make more than anticipated some buyers may receive the product after others - we will fulfill orders in the same order they were received).

story:
**Shark Tank Update!  We are so excited to have received 5 investment offers from the sharks! We have extremely limited inventory. The good news: as long as this message is up, we are in stock and shipping next business day. :) Hugs + have a great one!

 

Check your posture right now. 

 

How is your back? And your neck? Probably not too great. Or you’re already in so much pain that someone sent you here (hugs). BetterBack allows you to effortlessly sit in perfect posture, easing back pain.

 

 

Highlights

  • BetterBack® makes every chair ergonomic – Instead of spending hundreds of dollars on one chair, you can make every chair ergonomic. Lightweight and portable, you can throw BetterBack in your purse or backpack.
  • Next gen back support –  The keystone to good posture is the pelvis. Traditional back supports only focus on your lumbar spine. BetterBack stabilizes your pelvis, restoring your spine's natural curvature, and provides lumbar support. 
  • 15 minutes a day – Like dumbbells at a gym, BetterBack helps you build up your posture muscles. Wear it for as little as 15 minutes a day to achieve great posture when you stand or sit on your own.

Reviews

 

Take a few seconds to re-posture yourself right now. If you’re sitting, chances are your back isn’t touching your chair at all. That’s because most chairs aren’t ergonomic, and many actually encourage bad posture. BetterBack makes every chair ergonomic. Sit effortlessly in perfect posture at your desk. Or on a plane. Or at a game. You get the idea.

 

 

You get fast results and long term comfort. Put BetterBack on in 5 seconds flat!

 

 

 

 

 
Sit in perfect posture for minutes or hours. BetterBack can be adjusted to perfectly fit anyone from a child up to someone with a 42" waist. 

 

 

                        Get the Better Posture eBook FOR FREE!

 

 

 

Shipping

 

A few years ago, in the lovely year of 2012, I was the co-founder of a startup, Everest, that was building technology to help people live their dreams and achieve personal goals. I was mostly in front of a computer 12+ hours a day, but we also put on the Dream Series, which were meaningful events to help kickstart people's dreams. A few hours after an amazing obstacle course run through Golden Gate Park, my sciatica pain began. The pain and discomfort made it hard to concentrate, do great work and enjoy life.

I tried dozens of products, therapies and techniques to help with my back pain. Many of them had great features, but weren't full solutions for me. The Neo G Posture Brace: helped with alignment, but it was difficult to breathe and really bulky under my clothes; Easy Posture Lumbar Support: I still managed to wiggle and slump in my chair, and it only helped when I sat at my desk; the Nada Chair: brilliant knee form and pelvic stabilization, but gave me knee pain after just a few minutes of wear; LF Ultrasound: provided short-term pain relief, but it was fleeting; Memory Foam Knee Pillow: provided better alignment when I started sleep, but would end up in the bottom of my bed; and on and on.

A friend and I spent weeks tinkering with anything we could find to help get back support. There are still taped together take-out soup containers for lumbar support floating around my apartment. The first version of the BetterBack knees? A cut out from the top of a mega-sized protein bottle. 

 

I had no idea how many people were suffering from back pain when this all began. I felt way too young to have back pain, personally. Friends or colleagues would see me wearing the early versions of BetterBack and ask to try it. As soon as they did, I would get messages all the time: "Oh hey, I'm flying to New York on Tuesday, any chance I can borrow that thing you wear?" Or "My back is acting up, any chance I can just borrow it until Friday?" I had no idea so many people were suffering. I began to do more research and was blown away by what I found.  I decided to make more -- and invest time and money into making it better. 

 

 

 

Six prototypes later, I began working with manufacturers to build a high quality, well crafted and incredibly comfortable posture strap I would be proud to see my mom wear. And your mom too, if she doesn't have an awesome back.

 

I'm hoping to find people who will go on the journey with me to get a better back. I want to hear your story, what has worked and hasn't worked for you in the past, understand how BetterBack helps you and how it can help you better.  Please join me.

 

My mission is to help people be their best selves and unlock their full potential. Without health, that is impossible; it is the foundation for everything else.

I have spent the last few years learning about back pain, trying a huge range of products and therapies, and developing BetterBack with dozens on dozens of bad backs and amazing souls.

 

The relief and support people feel while wearing BetterBack—and even after—is truly amazing. No matter how many times or tools you’ve tried to sit pain free, BetterBack is like posture training wheels so you can experience and integrate good posture into your life for good.

 

Visit us at www.getbetterback.com or say hi, ask questions, get some back tips or share your pain at hi@getbetterback.com

 

 

 

 

How much should I wear it?

Sit in perfect posture for minutes or hours. It is comfortable to wear all day long, but even 15 minutes a day can greatly improve the quality of your life.

 

 

Will I look stupid wearing it?

It's hard to believe, but most people don't even notice when you're wearing it. I sit through meals, meetings and flights with BetterBack on and it's only when I'm taking it off that people tend to notice it, with a "you've been wearing that this whole time?!!" The thing that tends to happen next is someone shares their story of back pain and asks to try it on. 

 

 

How comfortable are the knee straps?

I have absolutely terrible knees (at one point I was put in two leg casts because of feet and knee injuries, later having surgery on my right knee). We spent a lot of time designing the knee cushions so that the force was widely distributed and comfortable for people who have knee problems *and* back problems.

Can I wear BetterBack while I drive?

Unfortunately, no. BetterBack is not safe to wear driving, or when you need quick leg mobility. It is great for sitting at your desk, eating, meeting, going to a movie, sitting on an airplane, meditating, etc. Note: you can wear BetterBack cross-legged!

  If you’re not in a place to financially contribute to our campaign, we still care about your posture and your health! Simply share our IndieGoGo page with your friends on Facebook or Twitter and we’ll give you the full copy of Better Posture for free. Just click on one of the share buttons below then enter your email where you’d like to receive the book here: http://bit.ly/2avx12I 
    
  Shipping
 When you back this project, you'll see shipping prices for your home country. We are shipping from the US which means our international friends will be responsible for local duties, fees, and taxes that may be added by your government.

We spent a lot of time designing the knee cushions so that the force was widely distributed and comfortable for people who have knee problems *and* back problems.
Can I wear BetterBack while I drive?
Unfortunately, no. BetterBack is not safe to wear driving, or when you need quick leg mobility. It is great for sitting at your desk, eating, meeting, going to a movie, sitting on an airplane, meditating, etc. Note: you can wear BetterBack cross-legged!

story:
Timebirds are revolutionary workout timers 

Purpose-built to the needs of athletes of all types

Two years ago, we found everyday athletes wanted the things they love about their wall-mounted gym timer, but built into a personal device. They told us to make it portable, make it durable, make it visible, make it sexy. So we did. 

After constant refining & testing, Timebirds took flight. 

 

Battle tested & approved by top athletes, gyms, trainers, and servicemen and women 

 

 

Designed for all sports, training & skill levels 

Why do people love Timebirds?

 

 

 

We designed Timebirds specifically for you to get the most out of every workout.

And people took notice...

 

Because a timer should be durable, easy to use, and highly visible...

And go with you everywhere...

Timebirds vs Your Current Timer

In most forms of training, you want a constantly visible time-source, keeping you accountable and getting the most out of each and every workout.

While there are many timing solutions on the market, none are versatile enough to be clearly seen and heard in multiple situations, while also giving the confidence that they will survive the rigors of the workout environment.

We’ve made Timebirds small enough to fit in your pocket but large enough to see during a workout.

 Timebirds' long-life battery and fast charging mean your workout is not limited by power point access. You can take it wherever you go.

 

 

The sleek design has been considered both inside and out, to maximize durability.

Timebirds have a consolidated circuit board that is fixed directly to the housing, strengthened further by inner ribs. This means there are no loose components. The thick, scratch-resistant, polycarbonate lens snaps directly into the housing, eliminating pressure points. It’s all encased in a high quality, non-slip, rubber skin that will not come off or crack over time, even in sweaty gym bags. Each button is optimally sized and placed for easy finger reach and moulded as part of the rubber skin, increasing overall water resistance and durability.

Each digit is illuminated by large, seven-segment LEDs and an anti-glare lens, to maximum visibility.

Powerful magnets have been fitted into the housing so Timebirds can be securely attached to any metallic (steel) surfaces, making them clearly visible during workouts. Their profile is thin enough to fit in your pocket but thick enough to stand by itself.

The result is a solid timer that feels great to hold and looks at home wherever you place it.

Available in a sexy matte black, it looks the part whether magnetized to a gym rig, a basketball post or while charging in the house.  We've also added a quartz crystal to provide the most stable, reliable and accurate clock signal. 

To cover all your training needs, Timebirds are programmed with five versatile workout modes you can easily cycle through with just one touch. 

The menu has been designed with intuitive mode indicators that use initials, rather than random numbers, for each setting.

  •  (UP) Count Up Timer
  •  (UP rd) Count Up Timer by round (eg. EMOM)
  •  (dn) Count Down Timer
  •  (nt) Custom Timer for Interval Training (eg. Tabata)
  •  (cL) Clock display

We set out to purpose-build Timebirds for the everyday athlete, however, we have found that our community keep finding new and exciting use cases. We'd love to hear how you use yours @timebirdstimers 

 1. Athletes of all types

From high-intensity workouts to training drills, no matter where you are, you can now take the visibility and accountability of a gym wall clock with you.

  •  At the gym – Now, you are always in control of where you want to see the time mid-workout
  •  Outside –  In the park, an outside gym, or on a court with high visibility 
  •  At home _ Like a professional gym clock but with the portability to place it where you need it
  •  On the go – travelling for work or on holiday, get the most out of your workouts wherever you are
  •  On social media – record your workouts with your phone while your timer is clearly visible

2. Personal trainers / Coaches

Timebirds give you a point of professional difference in and out of the gym. You no longer have to rely on your phone and risk having personal notifications appear, or keep looking at your wristwatch - now all your focus is on your client.

  • 1:1 sessions
  • Small group sessions
  • LIVE video content

3. Gyms / Institutions / Schools / Sports clubs

Give your members a truly unique experience with Timebirds timers.

  •  For open gym – no longer is it first come, first served for the wall timer; your members can grab a Timebird and manage their own workout with all the benefits of a highly visible wall clock
  •  For group classes – open up all sorts of opportunities to add new station based interval workouts, inside and outside, or with a personal timer clearly visible at each station

4. Other use cases

  •  Parents have told us they will use it for their kids. Timing their homework, their remaining screen time or to see how fast they can do their chores (good luck with that).
  •  Teachers, looking to gamify their classroom experience, focus students in 1:1 tutorials, or a whole room during an exam or speech.
  •  Cooks, have told us they want it for a clearly visible time in the kitchen. 

 What else will you use your Timebird for? Let us know in the comments section!

Each Timebird comes with:

  • 1x Timer
  • 1x USB to USB-C charging cable
  • 1x Instruction booklet

The Bird: 1x Timebirds timer

The bird and its protective cover : Designed to protect in two modes. Keep your Timebirds timer safe in travel and add another layer of durability during a workout. So you can make your Timebirds timer stand out from the flock, we are offering a range of colors to chose from.

 

The idea of building a pocket-sized version of a gym timer was born back in 2018.

The project was then taken into the Entrepreneurship program at the University of Melbourne, Australia. It took nearly 2 years to ideate, test and transform different proofs of concept and functioning prototypes. Our latest design is the result of several iterations and field tests by athletes of all fitness levels.

We have now reached a Design for Manufacture Stage, with all the functionalities that will enhance people's workout sessions. Our timeline allows for unexpected events in order to anticipate any delays due to the COVID19 situation. Our manufacturing partners are currently setting up for large scale production so we can start shipping Indiegogo orders across January 2021.

 

As dedicated fitness enthusiasts ourselves, we found it difficult to stay as accountable when in our home gym, hotel gyms, or training outside as we were when connected to the wall timer at our regular gym. We tried watches, which proved difficult whenever we needed two hands; phones, which resulted in cracked screens, phone call distractions, and any number of expletives as phones went to sleep just at the wrong moment. None quite hit the spot, and the more we talked to other athletes, gym owners, and personal trainers, we realised we weren’t alone - and, just like that, the concept of Timebirds, a purpose-built, personal workout timer was born.

Shipping & Taxes

You will be responsible for paying local Tax and duties when applicable. You will not always be required to pay duties or import tax, but it is important that you make yourself aware of the duties that apply in your country in case you are charged. 

Return Policy

Our intention is to do everything we possibly can to deliver a great, safe and reliable product to you on time. All the funds will be used towards organizing large scaled production and the launch of Timebirds. We will not offer refunds or returns, but in the unlikely event that you receive a damaged or faulty item, please report it immediately to your carrier upon receiving your package, and contact us support@timebirds.com. We greatly value our Indiegogo backers and will do everything we can to ensure you have a great experience with Timebirds.

story:
Short Summary

This is a side-line project that Dean and I are working on at Fluxx (www.fluxx.uk.com) -  a product and service innovation company.

Originally I asked Dean to help me build a slightly simpler version of this as I was sick of waiting for ages for my bus, or missing my bus, even though the stop is only a few minutes from my house.

The Transport for London (TFL) bus data source is relatively recent but it covers all of London, is pretty accurate and easy to access, but by the time I've found and opened an app, I might as well have just gone to the bus stop. The idea of departure boards is that it's always on, and easy to glance at on your wall at home or at work, making the information much more useful and timely. It's the same insight that led all smartphone makers to put the time on the lock screen rather than bury it in an app.

People in the office saw the prototype develop and quickly I started to get requests to make more. So we're wondering how wide that demand might be. The aim is to raise enough to work up a design for a product that can be mass produced (including the software needed to make it easy to control the device through the internet).

If we can get this first, simple product off the ground, we have plans to extend it for other services (such as rail, weather and your kids' gym kit), and some pretty exciting ideas for next stage physical devices.

What We Need & What You Get

We would like to gauge interest in the device by raising enough money to make 20 prototype devices to put out on Alpha test.

For anyone who supports us with over £50, we will build you a device, pre-programmed to your specific bus stops, and you will become one of our Alpha testers. We won’t ask for the device back at the end of the trial, and it will still work. We are prepared to consider requests for it to be coded in other ways, e.g. to weather or train times. Provided they have an accessible data feed, we can consider it.

This trial will allow us to gather enough evidence to drive our next campaign which will seek to take us towards mass production, in which we will:

  • Develop the setup experience - getting it seamlessly onto wifi
  • Create the customisation interface - making it easy to code the device to your needs
  • Plan the mass production and tooling requirements

The Impact
We think this is just one idea for humanising the sort of technology normally accessed from smartphones. Why not incorporate data like this more directly in your physical surroundings?

Other Ways You Can Help
If you don't want to contribute cash, we'd love to hear your ideas for similar products and markets.

Please like and share us.

How it works

A few people have asked questions about what the device actually does and how it works. So the device has two 10-LED arrays. As it currently stands, the top 10 LEDs provide a count down to the next bus at the stop outside my house in a simple way: 10 LEDs = 10 mins or more to the bus, 9 LEDs = 9 mins etc. When it gets close (under 1 min), the function switches to 1 LED = 6 seconds, and the whole lot flash. In my case, this is the point at which I need to get out the door or I will miss the bus. It would be possible to add a time difference (e.g. if it's  a five minute walk to the stop, we could subtract 5 mins from all the times). Obviously, in the long term, we'd be hoping this could be the sort of configuration the user could self-manage.

The second set of 10 LEDs shows the second bus. This is most useful when two buses are close together, meaning you've got a little longer before you need to rush off.

The design approach is that the device should be inconspicuous and its purpose not obvious. We hope to make the case more simple and elegant in future iterations (currently white plastic).

story:
Please take a moment to read this and share across your social network.

Late in the evening of Thursday, December 20th, a dear friend Raisa Buketovs' home was taken to a sudden and swift-moving electrical fire. Thankfully, Raisa was not at home at the time of the blaze and is safe. 

Tragically, the Echo Park home in which she has resided her entire life was completely destroyed, all of its contents lost; including her beloved dogs; innocent victims of the unrelenting blaze. 

Media coverage of the tragedy:

http://onscenevideo.tv/echo-park-house-fire-2

As Raisa struggles to deal with this catastrophe, she has nothing to her name except the clothing on her back. Raisa does have home owners insurance but it may be weeks before she sees any financial assistance due to the paperwork involved as well as the holidays approaching. In addition, this past week, Raisa'a employer notified her she will be subject to layoffs at the beginning of February.

What We Need to Help Raisa

  • Though money doesn't mean anything to Raisa in the wake of the inestimable loss, she will need a whole new everything. With even the smallest donation, we can help replenish at least some of the essential things she needs so desperately at this time. By using the link provided to donate, funds go directly into Raisa's Paypal account.

Other Ways You Can Help

Of course some of us are unable to contribute, but that doesn’t mean we can’t help:

  • Clothing donations: Raisa wears a size 8 in dresses, pants and skirts and a medium blouse or top. She wears a size 11 shoe. Professional, interview type clothing would be the most beneficial for her. I am happy to coordinate pick up of these items from you in Los Angeles. Please contact Joy Ivy via Facebook private message.
  • Naturally, Raisa is shellshocked - the full gravity of the event not yet palpable, some deep emotional trauma is iminant. Any information on grief / trauma counseling services following an event of this magnitude would be greatly appreciated.
  • Please repost this note on your feed, help us reach far and wide.

Thank you for sharing your time and I wish you all the very best holiday season and new year.

story:
We are Joe and Patty Baughman campaigning to help friends Dan and Teresa Wetzel with medical expenses resulting from a home building accident.

On November 3rd, while building his own home in Snohomish, Washington, our friend Dan Wetzel had a nail deflected deep into his eye. As Dan and his wife Teresa had recently moved back to the Seattle area to be near their children and grand children, they did not yet have insurance coverage at their new jobs. The accident has resulted in loss of sight, loss of job, an unfinished home, and $35,000 dollars in medical bills to date with additional surgery and other medical services needed.

We first met Dan and Teresa while building our own home in Southern Utah in 2003. Patty and I had just moved here from Jackson, Wyoming and they had recently moved to the area from Seattle. By coincidence I ended up working with Dan for almost 2 years building homes. He is an outstanding craftsman and at the same time one of the most humble men I know. Dan is the kind of guy everyone enjoys working with because he tackles every task with positive energy and a great sense of humor. Dan and Teresa thoroughly enjoyed exploring southern Utah for 10 years but family drew them back to the Seattle area in late 2012.

We want to help Dan and Teresa because they are not only really great people that are always helpful and inspiring to others, but would never ask for help themselves. Our goal is to give them hope and some financial relief in tackling the initial medical bills from this accident while facing additional surgery and more medical expenses.

We have involved our Grub Hub camp kitchen business in helping Dan and Teresa because we originally expected to donate some of the Grub Hub products for a raffle to help with medical expenses. Finding that raffles are not allowed, we have provided discounts on our products and worked with Dan and Teresa and other friends with businesses to develop more great prizes that we think are now even better than the original plan.

The prizes for our contributors include HAND MADE items from Teresa, a fun T-shirt design, a shop poster inspired by the accident and some really steep discounts on the Grub Hub camp kitchens (www.grubhubusa.com). There is also free paddle board rentals for folks in S. Utah and discounts at Global Treasurers in Jackson, Wyoming. As our video says we hope the old fashioned idea of a pitching in to help someone in need while earning some fun prizes will get Dan and Teresa through this difficult period.  

                         

M, L, XL PLAY shirt black on white
"DANGER BELOW --   Inexperienced Rider on Open Course"


M, L, XL Brew Patrol shirt color ink on white
"World's Largest Growler"



     

18" x 24"   EVERY SHOP SHOULD HAVE THIS POSTER ON THE WALL..

Prizes will be shipped expediently and discount prizes will be issued within one business day at the close of this campaign. All proceeds less base cost of the T-shirt and poster prizes and any taxes or fees will go to Dan and Teresa. We are hoping to complete shipments before Christmas.

We really hope you will help Dan and Teresa with one of the contributions. If you can't help, PLEASE forward to your friends who may.

Volunteers Needed! If you are in the Seattle area and interested in helping Dan and the family finish the home please contact us!


Thank You. Joe and Patty Baughman on behalf of Dan and Teresa

All proceeds less base cost of the T-shirt and poster prizes and any taxes or fees will go to Dan and Teresa. We are hoping to complete shipments before Christmas.We really hope you will help Dan and Teresa with one of the contributions. If you can't help, PLEASE forward to your friends who may. 
Volunteers Needed! If you are in the Seattle area and interested in helping Dan and the family finish the home please contact us!Thank You. Joe and Patty Baughman on behalf of Dan and Teresa

story:
Thank you for taking the time to visit our campaign,

Our family member Brad was diagnosed with stage 4a throat cancer in June. His treatment plan at this time includes three rounds of chemotherapy, followed by eight weeks of radiation.

Brad unfortunately does not have insurance, and currently he is unable to work, that is why we are reaching out to you to raise funds to help defray his medical bills.

Brad is the oldest of four boys and he was born and raised in Rockford Il.
Their parents died in a car accident when they were very young. The paternal
side of the family raised the two eldest boys while the maternal side raised
the two youngest. Both sides of the family did a great job making sure that
the brothers stayed close growing up and they remain that way today.

Brad graduated from Jefferson High School in 1978. Right out of high-school he decided to work at his Uncle’s machine shop. Shortly there after he moved to Florida where he live for approximately 10 years. He decided to move back to Rockford, and he became a volunteer firefighter and first responder with the New Milford Fire Department for 6 years, he loved being able to help people in their time of need. Brad also loves the open road, seeing new places and meeting new people. It only made sense for Brad to become a truck driver.

Brad is the sweetest, most caring person, one would ever meet. He would give you the shirt off of his back, with no questions asked.

We are thankful that this is a treatable disease and hopeful that it is curable as well. We have faith he will survive it, but the medical bills are piling up fast.

Please help us, not only smash, but far exceed our minimum goal.

We want Brad to be able to put all of his focus on fighting the cancer and winning, without the distraction of mounting bills.

 All proceeds will go towards his medical bills.

Please help us spread the word, and share this campaign with your friends and family.

Support the FIGHTERS, admire the SURVIVORS, honor the TAKEN and never, ever give up HOPE.

Thank you from all of the Opsahl family, we really truly appreciate any donations you have given to Brad. Words of encouragement are also welcomed.

 

May God Bless you and yours.

story:
WHAT  "THERMOBAND" DOES 

Monitors core body temperature to notify parent, family member, caregivers, via Bluetooth™- to mobile devices of changes so appropriate action can be taken, when needed. 

ThermoBand is device provides comfort of constant fever monitoring and peace of mind in knowing that your loved one's temperature is constantly monitored. ThermoBand is a device that is based on the idea of recording the changes in temperature of the body instead of the absolute temperature. 

ThermoBand provides an accurate body temperature of your child who is suffering from fever.
ThermoBand apparatus is a device based on the idea of detecting temperature changes and not absolute temperature. 

HOW DOES IT WORK

Our device is based on the idea of detecting the change in temperature of the body. Thus, we can use the skin temperature as a parameter for measuring core temperature variation. Our temperature sensing band aid will be fixed on the forehead/body of your child. If the fever of your child increases at night, it will generate the alarm. Now, suppose a condition that your child is suffering from a 102 degree F temperature at 10 PM. The only way to keep an eye on the temperature is that you don’t sleep, wake the child from time to time for the inspecting the fever. Or the other option is to use this device and it will keep complete monitoring of your child’s health. Also, it will warn you before the situation becomes severe.

YOUR CHILD comes home from school one day not feeling well. By the end of the night, he is coughing and has a fever of 99. You take his temperature before he goes to sleep. It is now pushing 101. YOU give him/her a fever reducer. He goes to sleep, but you don’t. You go into your bedroom, lay down and set your alarm for an hour so you can check on your son and see if the fever reducing medication is working. You check his fever again and it has gone down to 101. You set your alarm to check on him in another hour. You worry and lose sleep.

Next time your child gets down with a fever, ThermoBand is the device you should use. With this, you will not have to check your child’s fever with a thermometer every 2-3 hours. Also, it will allow you to understand whether the medicine treatment which you have opted for is actually showing its effect or not.


ThermoBand is a modern innovation, which measures the body temperature changes caused due to fever. 

We know that the exact body temperature is not easy to measure. The temperature probe has to be placed in body cavities or swallowed to get right body temperature. The skin temperature usually has no relation to core temperature, and therefore it gets tricky to use unwearable device for the purpose.

SPECIFICATIONS

Take a look at our package configurations which will help you understand our specifications appropriately:


Our wearable ThermoBand product comes with one ThermoBand device and five additional replaceable adhesive. 

  • Easy to stick on and flexes to fit your forehead, neck other positions.
  • Green LED shows fever drop Red LED shows fever going up.
  • Battery lasts 1-2 years in typical use and replaceable 
  • ThermoBand with Bluetooth interface to smartphone generated alarms and calls/notify to multiples phones

Additional Applications

TEAM BEHIND THE INNOVATION

At FirstWearable, we’re a group of professionals who are passionate about creating innovative products that simplify everyday life. We’re tireless in our pursuit to discover new solutions. Our goal is to make life easier and more efficient. 

Fevers are one of the most upsetting and erratic maladies that people face. If the body temperature rises, severe measures may need to be taken. Doctors recommend that if temperatures continue to exceed 101 degrees after receiving fever-reducing medicines, a wet pack or sponge should be applied. If a person’s temperature rises above 104 degrees rashes may appear and emergency room visit is urgently necessary. Keeping all the inconvenience and fears that a fever causes, we thought of creating a product which could help the parents alleviate their worries. And, so the idea of bringing FirstWearable into existence clicked us.

WHAT IS OUR GOAL

We are aiming to develop a secure and easy-to-wear gadget that is highly reliable and safe for the users. One can easily and efficiently keep an eye on the body temperature of the kids; adults as well. This gadget is easy to use as compared       to the traditional thermometers, especially when you need close monitoring of the patient.

ThermoBand can greatly help children in communities with limited hospitals and clinics, as well as limited financial and medical resources. Many children are fortunate enough to have caring parents who can monitor their sickness and fever, but we recognize there are also those who do not. For many there are fever reducing medications in the next room, but for many there are not. Our goal as we build ThermoBand’s financial profitability to is to utilize our innovation to help children who suffer from a lack of care and resources. In the U.S, that might be providing ThermoBand to a clinic servicing a poor neighborhood. Abroad, it may mean supplying the local physician an ability to monitor many children suffering from an epidemic. It should be understood, we have no desire nor intention to use our philanthropic vision and goals a marketing tactic. No “one for one.” No “1 dollar of each product purchased.” Very simply put, our firm’s goal is to make everyone’s lives simpler and better.

Monetary Goals

At $75,000, we will upgrade the product by adding more reliable sensors and integrating the product to one’s cell phone via GPS. Getting a warning alarm or message on a cell phone will help you in even close and efficient monitoring.

At $125,000, We will start a large scale manufacturing of this product. We will distribute this product in our whole state covering every city and street of our state via medical stores.

At $250,000, we will distribute this product nationwide, covering all the cities and territories on USA.

HOW CAN YOU HELP

In this mission to make fever-monitoring better, we need you to support us on every point. We need your help in making this product reliable, superior and efficient. Your precious feedback, monetary support and guidance will help us in creating a product that can change our lives.

At FirstWearable, we want to involve the community in the product development process. You’ll be an integral part of our process all along the way.

PROJECT FUNDING

We think this innovation can really help in simplifying our daily lives and so, we are asking for your monetary and motivational support. With you and Kickstart, we can take FirstWearable to a distinct height of success in the field of health and wellness.

story:
A team of physicians and nurses is going to Bantayan Island and its environs in the Philippines (some areas are only accessible by rowboat) -- which were ravaged by Super Typhoon Haiyan (Yolanda), destroying about 90 percent of the island's structures. The team -- many of the members Filipino-Americans -- will be providing free care and medications from March 20-30, 2014. They will be paying much of their own expenses, not to mention they will be unable to see their regular practice patients for the duration of the trip. Donations are still needed to cover the costs.

Short Summary

Contributors fund ideas they can be passionate about and to people they trust. Here are some things to do in this section:

  • Introduce yourself and your background.
  • Briefly describe your campaign and why it’s important to you.
  • Express the magnitude of what contributors will help you achieve.

Remember, keep it concise, yet personal. Ask yourself: if someone stopped reading here would they be ready to make a contribution?

What We Need & What You Get

Break it down for folks in more detail:

  • Explain how much funding you need and where it’s going. Be transparent and specific—people need to trust you to want to fund you.
  • Tell people about your unique perks. Get them excited!
  • Describe where the funds go if you don’t reach your entire goal.

The Impact

Feel free to explain more about your campaign and let people know how the difference their contribution will make:

  • Explain why your project is valuable to the contributor and to the world.
  • Point out your successful track record with projects like this (if you have one).
  • Make it real for people and build trust.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean they can’t help:

  • Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about your campaign.
  • Remind them to use the Indiegogo share tools!

And that’s all there is to it.

story:
Baby Adriana was born with Junctional Epidermolysis Bullosa (EB) on November 23, 2012, and she is finally at home with her family.  Epidermolysis Bullosa (EB) is a rare genetic connective tissue disorder that causes painful blistering of the skin and the mucous membranes.  It affects one in every 50,000 live births and can often times be fatal within the first year. Those affected lack the proteins that prevent the skin layers from acting independently from one another resulting in extreme fragility of the skin.  This means that the slightest of touches, even a hug can cause excruciatingly painful blisters and wounds.  These wounds are very susceptible to infections which can often times be lethal.
In order to protect the skin from infections and additional wounds, one must be wrapped in special bandages that do not adhere to the skin.  These bandages must be changed frequently...a tedious and painful process.  However since there is no cure, this is the only effective treatment.
EB comes with numerous challenges aside from dressing changes.  Despite any amount of care, wounds still occur and with the wounds comes scarring.  This scarring can cause deformities in the hands and feet as the skin begins to fuse together often resulting in a clubbing effect.  Another complication as a result of the chronic damage to the skin is cancer, which it typically fatal in these cases.
Due to the many costs associated with Baby Adriana's care and medical needs, her family in in need of some assistance.  If you are able, please consider helping.  Thank you!

story:
Led By Christ To India

 

At first I thought extreme exhaustion was just an undiscussed part of midlife. Who knew it was actually cancer?  In case you're asking why I got cancer, so am I!  Most people who get cancer also have no known genetic factor contributing to their illness, as I have none.  

Somehow, a person can be a lifelong nonsmoker, nondrinker, can "eat right" and get outdoors exercise, all of which I did, but can STILL get cancer. And, as it turns out, cancer doesn't always form a lump, at least not in early stages.  The signs can be ever-so-subtle, as they were for me.  You can "miss" them.

Chemo works well for SOME kinds of cancer, but doesn't work well for most. (In fact, survival of stage 3 and 4 cancers hasn't improved in over 50 years.)

Despite months of brutal traditional chemotherapy treatments and major surgery, the cancer still spread and doctors said, "call Hospice."  (I refused.)  That was two years ago.  But Christ was, and is, still at work in this situation.

What if there were another way, a new way that can restore the GIFT of vibrant health for many more productive years?

By a series of unusual circumstances I see as His grace, The Lord made me aware that there IS another way.  The US-based Munogenics company, (www.munogenics.com) has developed it.  It's called GIFT and it's a breakthrough new nontoxic cancer treatment now in clinical trials on the very first human test subjects in Pune, India.  Munogenics calls me "an excellent candidate" and has already accepted me as a test subject. All I need to do is get there and stay in India for one month.  That's why I need your help.  Disabled by the cancer and unable to work now, I can't afford this on my own.

This GIFT technology is solid science, the "real deal." 

I'm ready to put my body into this extraordinary research, if you will put whatever money you can afford into getting me there.

If you can't donate, pray and if you use social sites, link this effort.

Time is of the essence for me now, but with your help, there's still a very good chance my own life will have a second half and the whole world will have a better way to deal with solid-tumor types of cancer. 

There's even hope that someday soon, GIFT can become a preventive for most cancers.  Wouldn't that be great, if cancer became a rare disease? This reearch stands a good chance of getting us to that future.  

What are my plans once I've recovered?  Working again, gardening again, more gourmet cooking, more art, (I've been gallery-represented), and doing more volunteering for cats and dogs in need.  There's so much left to do!

Let's do this!  It may be the most important thing you and I ever get to do!

story:
My name is Stephanie Stuart Trinder, the mother of a determined and spunky two-year-old and the COO of small non-profit called Wild4life operating in the western tip of Zimababwe. While visiting our programs in August, I met a little boy named Nqobizitha ("Conquerer" in English) and his mother, Precious. At the time, Conquerer was two, considerably small for his age and unable to walk as a result of having a condition called hydrocephalus, also known as “water on the brain.” What struck me about Precious was her grace as she looked so adoringly at her son and pleaded for help. She told me how her husband recently left her because he considers Conquerer a curse to the family. As with many children in this area, Precious (one of seven children) finished school at 15 because her parents couldn't afford school fees. At 19 she has no job.

A mother myself, it was impossible not to relate to Precious, but even more difficult not to compare Conquerer's limitations to my toddler who is thriving here in the US. Conquerer's condition falls outside of the mandate of our organization, and it became apparent that helping him would become a personal mission. 

I soon discovered that Conquerer was not the only child in the community with hydropcephalus. Another boy, Praise, is a seven-year-old unable to use his legs. Praise moves around by lifting his legs and shuffling along the ground. His mother died when he was just a year old and he's now cared for by his grandmother while his father looks after his other two children and struggles to make enough money to get Praise treatment. Until now, Praise has received some medical attention, but his father can no longer afford any treatment. Despite his challenges, Praise speaks four languages and is a clever boy, but needs full-time care to carry out basic daily functions, which is more than his 63-year-old grandmother can shoulder on top of taking care of seven other grandchildren.

Not only will Conquerer and Praise never develop like young children should, they can die if they don't receive the appropriate treatment.

What We Need

Like much of the medical treatment we take for granted in the US, what is considered an accessible and routine procedure in the developed world is entirely unaffordable and unavailable to these little boys in Zimbabwe. However, there is a US-based organization called CURE that runs a hospital in Lusaka, Zambia (about 400 miles away, an overnight bus ride for these family) that will treat these two children at no cost to the families. 

My goal is to raise enough money to get these children and their parents the passports, transportation and food they need to travel to Lusaka and stay at this incredible facility (http://cure.org/hospitals/zambia/#about) while the boys get the appropriate treatment. This will cost $1,250 per child, which means we need your help raising $2,500. We must get these children quality treatment as soon as possible, before it is too late. Please consider giving to this campaign, even a small amount matters. I will be back in Zimbabwe in the coming year, and I hope to be able to report to you that Conquerer and Praise are thriving. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Many of us give our time and money generously to important causes. If you are unable to give at this time:

• Get the word out and make some noise about this campaign - post it on Facebook or send this link to your friends and family.

• Use the Indiegogo share tools.
story_txt:
My name is Stephanie Stuart Trinder, the mother of a
determined and spunky two-year-old and the COO of small non-profit called
Wild4life operating in the western tip of Zimababwe. While visiting our
programs in August, I met a little boy named Nqobizitha ("Conquerer"
in English) and his mother, Precious. At the time, Conquerer was two,
considerably small for his age and unable to walk as a result of having a
condition called hydrocephalus, also known as “water on the brain.” What
struck me about Precious was her grace as she looked so adoringly at her son
and pleaded for help. She told me how her husband recently left her because he
considers Conquerer a curse to the family. As with many children in this area,
Precious (one of seven children) finished school at 15 because her parents
couldn't afford school fees. At 19 she has no job.
A mother myself, it was impossible
not to relate to Precious, but even more difficult not to compare Conquerer's
limitations to my toddler who is thriving here in the US. Conquerer's condition
falls outside of the mandate of our organization, and it became apparent that
helping him would become a personal mission. 
I soon discovered that Conquerer was
not the only child in the community with hydropcephalus. Another boy, Praise,
is a seven-year-old unable to use his legs. Praise moves around by lifting his
legs and shuffling along the ground. His mother died when he was just a year
old and he's now cared for by his grandmother while his father looks after his
other two children and struggles to make enough money to get Praise treatment.
Until now, Praise has received some medical attention, but his father can no
longer afford any treatment. Despite his challenges, Praise speaks four
languages and is a clever boy, but needs full-time care to carry out basic
daily functions, which is more than his 63-year-old grandmother can shoulder on
top of taking care of seven other grandchildren.
Not only will Conquerer and Praise
never develop like young children should, they can die if they don't receive
the appropriate treatment.

Like much of the medical treatment we
take for granted in the US, what is considered an accessible and routine
procedure in the developed world is entirely unaffordable and unavailable to
these little boys in Zimbabwe. However, there is a US-based organization called
CURE that runs a hospital in Lusaka, Zambia (about 400 miles away, an overnight
bus ride for these family) that will treat these two children at no cost to the
families. 
My goal is to raise enough money to get these children and
their parents the passports, transportation and food they need to travel to
Lusaka and stay at this incredible facility (http://cure.org/hospitals/zambia/#about)
while the boys get the appropriate treatment. This will cost $1,250 per child,
which means we need your help raising $2,500. We must get these children
quality treatment as soon as possible, before it is too late. Please consider
giving to this campaign, even a small amount matters. I will be back in
Zimbabwe in the coming year, and I hope to be able to report to you that Conquerer
and Praise are thriving. 
Other Ways You Can Help
Many of us give our time and money
generously to important causes. If you are unable to give at this time:
• Get the word out and make some noise
about this campaign - post it on Facebook or send this link to your friends and
family.• Use the Indiegogo share tools.

story:
Christen White [1979-2002]

September 12, 2000.  I get a call from the Emergency Room at The University of Tennessee Medical Center in Knoxville where my 20-year-old daughter Christen was taken when she fainted at the UT Library.  It’s a doctor who is telling me that he thinks she might have primary pulmonary hypertension and that this is a very serious situation.  I tell him I’ll be on the next flight down.

Is this related to the shortness of breath she’s been having for a couple of years, I wonder? Her doctor at home told her she should lose some weight and that would probably solve that problem. Lately she’d been having trouble climbing stairs, but still the doctor didn’t seem very concerned. Lose weight, he said.

But now it turns out she might have a fatal disease that seemed to have snuck up on us without warning. I mean, if her doctor wasn’t concerned about the shortness of breath, why should we be worried, right?

When I get to Knoxville, Christen is in Intensive Care. The doctors tell me they have done a right heart catheterization and have confirmed the diagnosis: it’s pulmonary hypertension and they don’t know what caused it.  They tell me to get her to an academic medical center where they can care for her. And they tell me the illness she has is often fatal within two years of diagnosis.

I call my cousin who is a pulmonologist and tell him what’s going on. Take Christen to an academic medical center, he says. She’s at an academic medical center now, I say, and they’re telling me to take her someplace else. My cousin says to take her wherever they suggest because he’s not familiar with the options in the south. The UT doctors suggest two places and we pick the one closest to Christen’s home.

We go there and she is placed on a drug called Flolan – a drug administered by a small pump through a tube in her chest. They scare the hell out of us by saying that if the pump fails or if the tube pulls out, she’s likely to die in minutes. We are reeling from the devastating diagnosis.

After a week in the hospital she goes home and later goes back to school, although her doctor tells her not to. She wants to finish her final semester and get married. It’s unclear whether this is a bad idea or not, and we’re not getting very much in the way of answers.

June, 2001:  After being very unhappy with the follow up care and the lack of information, Christen asks to be taken to the other option we were given in Knoxville, namely The Vanderbilt University Medical Center in Nashville.

It is now about two and a half years since Christen first began experiencing shortness of breath and nine months since her diagnosis, and we still have not regained our balance. We’re still reeling. We’re in denial about how bad this can be. We’re scared and confused.

The doctors and nurses at Vanderbilt seem to know what they’re doing and we’re feeling more confident. Then they tell Christen that her disease is advanced and that she needs a heart-lung transplant. We look into what this is about and learn that while it is the only ultimate solution for pulmonary hypertension, it comes with its own dire consequences, including death during surgery and a poor prognosis after that. She decides to wait. We want to support her as best we can, but have no idea what the best thing is to do or where to find out. This is before we knew of the Pulmonary Hypertension Association.

May 2002:  It’s been almost a year since Christen went to Vanderbilt and she seems to be doing okay – not great, but okay.  She calls to tell me she has a scholarship to attend the Pulmonary Hypertension Association’s Conference in California and asks if I’ll go with her.

In June at the Conference in California it becomes clearer to Christen and me just how sick she really is. I had just seen her in April and now a couple of months later she is clearly doing much worse. I still can’t believe in my heart what my head is telling me: Christen is dying. I get the feeling she knows this, but she doesn’t say it.

Through the summer and into the fall I speak with her almost daily and with her mother weekly. I can tell things are not going well. Her nurse at Vanderbilt says there are no other options other than a transplant. Christen agrees to go on the transplant list, but there are examinations and interviews that have to happen before that can be finalized.

October 19, 2002: Christen flies to New Jersey to visit us and, when I pick her up at the airport she can barely walk. I say this trip was not a good idea and wish I had not agreed to it. She stays a week and spends most of the time sitting on the sofa. Her hands and feet are cold and she aches all over. I begin to suspect that the end is coming, but push the thought out of my mind whenever it intrudes. Christen says don’t worry, Dad. I’m seeing my doctor in Nashville next week and we’ll figure something out.

So off she goes to Nashville for what she thought was a routine visit.  She arrived at the hospital on Tuesday with her mother. She was unexpectedly admitted to the hospital. I arrived on Thursday and stayed with Christen in her room. On Friday morning her doctor told us that her heart was dangerously enlarged and that there was nothing that could be done. He told her she had weeks, maybe days to live.

By Saturday, November 2 all of her family was gathered around her, and after she has spent a little time with everyone she lost consciousness

Christen died just after midnight on Sunday, November 3, 2002 – 782 days after being diagnosed and God only knows how long after experiencing her first symptoms of pulmonary hypertension.

~ Steve White, Chair-Elect, Board of Trustees, Pulmonary Hypertension Association, and Christen's Dad


Pediatric Pulmonary Hypertension

Pulmonary hypertension is high blood pressure of the arteries that go from the heart to the lungs.  One of the symptoms is difficulty breathing. Try breathing through a straw for as long as you can stand it. This will give you an idea of what it might be like to live with pulmonary hypertension - a disease of the heart and lungs.  


While there are now 11 drugs approved for adults with PH, there are no drugs approved for children with this devastating disease. Help us find a cure, and along the way to a cure better treatments, for pediatric pulmonary hypertension.  Even a small contribution will make an enormous difference, and may even save the life of a beautiful child.


What Is Needed

Kids are not "miniature adults".  So the treatments available for adults with pulmonary hypertension don't work the same way for kids. Research on treatments for pediatric pulmonary hypertension lags about 10 years behind research for adult treatments  That's why there is an urgent need for research funds and for funds to mentor young physicians in the field. Please help us close this gap by making a generous contribution to the Robyn Barst Pediatric Research Fund.

Who Was Robyn Barst?

Robyn Barst graduated from medical school in 1979 and began a long career in pediatric cardiology. In the 1980s there was only a handful of doctors around the world who were interested in pulmonary hypertension and Dr. Barst was virtually the only doctor in the world interested in pediatric pulmonary hypertension. She was a pioneer in the field and had a hand in every major development in the field from the early 1980s right up until her death in April, 2013.  

She was mentor and teacher to virtually all of the top physicians around the world who specialize in pediatric PH. Over the course of her career she published a total of 1,861 scholarly articles in medical journals, most of them concerning pulmonary hypertension. That is an astounding rate of more than one article a week for 34 years!

When she was diagnosed with lung cancer she made the decision to provide the seed money for a fund to sponsor medical research in the field of pediatric pulmonary hypertension and to provide mentoring to young doctors entering the field. 

We can honor her memory and her dedicated career by helping expand the fund so that more awards to young scientists and clinicians can be awareded each year.


The Impact

The field of adult pulmonary hypertension research has advanced dramatically over the last 10 years. Together, we can make the same thing happen for kids with PH by contributing a little or a lot to the Robyn Barst Pediatric Research Fund. Through research, we will find better treatments, and ultimately a cure for PH. 

A contribution of ANY amount will make an important difference in the lives of thousands of kids. You can help save many lives even with a small donation.

Other Ways You Can Help

You might be only able to contribute a little, or maybe not at all.  But you can still help kids with PH by spreading the word about this important campaign to your friends, family, co-workers, and neighbors. Please help us fight back against this terrible disease.  Please.

For more information about pulmonary hypertension, visit the Pulmonary Hypertension Association web site at www.phassociation.org.

Thank you!

story:
Short Summary

  • Hi, my name is Laura MacKinnon and I'm a senior at the University of Pennsylvania. I struggled with an eating disorder for years and now that I've reached a place of health and peace with myself, it is my mission to stimulate conversation about this tabooed topic and promote healthy body image. I believe eating disorders are 100% preventable and that we all have a role in prevention. I created this group, Penn Poised, and the Come As You Are campaign, to start to chip away at the unreasonable societal standards of beauty and help us embrace ourselves as we are.
  • Contributors will help us fund a photo shoot campaign that involves students revealing their body insecurities or showing off something they love about their body. 

What We Need & What You Get

  • We need $500 to complete our body insecurity photo shoot.
  • ALL contributors will get a personalized thank you note from Penn Poised.

The Impact

  • Contributors will making a big difference in creating a campus (and eventually a world!) culture of inclusivity and acceptance, a place where we value our bodies as uniquely beautiful. 

Other Ways You Can Help

  • If you can't personally contribute, please share with friends!
