story:
From John’s wife;

As a wife, it has been really hard to see my husband go through the degenerative process that is Ehlers-Danlos syndrome.  We first met nearly 22 years ago, in the late summer of 1991, and we instantly fell in love.  John asked me to marry him two weeks later, and I said yes.   John was such a hard worker back then, but he already had some issues with his health.  He was on call 24/7 for his job, and he absolutely loved every minute of it.  He would work 16 hours, come home exhausted, then have to go out again in the middle of the night, but he never once complained.  When it comes to family, and people in general, John has always held fast to the ethics that his grandparents instilled in him as a child; you always help people, no matter what.  John helped anyone that was in need, and he never stopped helping people, even when he was sick.  When it came to family and friends, no matter how big or complicated the job, he would do everything that he could, to fulfill every request that he could, and he would do so without asking for, or accepting, any payment at all.  Over the years he slowly became a different person due to the constant pain and frequent injuries.  Where he was once so sweet, friendly and easy going, he was now becoming increasingly irritable, angry, and short tempered.  None of his doctors could explain what was causing all of these problems, and some questioned whether there actually were any, but that would all soon change.  When the day finally came in 1997 that John could no longer work due to his frequent injuries and the constant, unrelenting pain that he was in, we were both devastated.  John has a very specific view of what the terms husband and father mean, and without the ability to provide for his family, he felt that he was fulfilling neither.  In 1999 John was diagnosed with Ehlers-Danlos syndrome type 3, and finally the questions that we had been asking for years were beginning to be answered.  Initially it was very difficult for both of us to deal with the finality of his diagnosis.  There were major implications now with regard to his lifespan, our daughter, and his various medications, not to mention the unknown variables.  The changes in his health and his way of life have been dramatic to say the least, and his constant decline has been as evident, as it has been upsetting, to everyone around him.  He is unable to eat most foods as they upset his stomach, so he tends to eat the same things day in and day out, sometimes for years at a time.  He doesn’t sleep well at all, and he has difficulty with his memory as well as with concentrating.  Some of his joints dislocate very easily, and he once went for more than a week with a dislocated right shoulder.  He has become very adept at hiding his pain from everyone, including myself.  John doesn’t like it when people worry about him, especially those of us that love him, so he hides his pain from everyone.  Sometimes he can’t hide it, and it upsets him to the point that he apologizes to us.  Even when he is suffering from the most agonizing pain, and suffering so badly that he can no longer hide it from us, he maintains an optimism that I honestly find frustrating at times.  He has a saying, and whenever someone asks him how he’s doing, or how much pain he is in, he always tries to reassure us that he’s ok by saying; “It could always be worse”.  We have been married for 19 years, and I continue to love him more and more, each and every day that we are together.  If I could have one wish, I would wish that he could be comfortable on a daily basis, and my main goal is to try to help him live a more comfortable life.  I believe that he deserves to be able to live his life to the fullest, and right now, in large part due to the medications that he is on, that is impossible.  He has effectively lost the last 15 ½ years of his life to Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, and I do not want that to continue.

Thank you, Sherri Mathias.    

 

From John's daughter Katie;

Growing up my entire life I remember many things about my dad being sick.  Most, if not all, were hard to deal with, but some were downright unbearable.  Things such as hearing the whispers behind closed doors, the often tearful phone calls to my grandmother, and, on a few occasions, reading the "goodbye" notes that were left as my father went to the hospital for yet another surgery.  It has not only been hard on me, but it has been hard on my mother as well.  My parents always tried to put on a smile and tell me that everything was "ok", but as the years went by, and I continued to see the same, pained expression on my father’s face, it became more and more apparent that it was not "ok".  I was 3 ½ years old when the doctors diagnosed my dad with Ehlers-Danlos syndrome.  He had already lost his ability to work by then, so my mom had to go to work just to keep us afloat.  Even though I don’t remember much from those early days, I do remember the days that followed.  I remember coming home from school every night and seeing him laying on the couch drenched in sweat, and I remember wishing that there was something that I could do or some comfort that I could give to him.  I remember the countless apologies from my dad because he felt that he had failed me as a father, and to this day I know that he wishes he could have given me the life that he wanted to give me.  It pains me to see him so upset, and to see him being so hard on himself all the time.  Growing up knowing that your father is in so much pain that he can’t even get out of bed, and that no matter what you do you can’t make him feel better, you can’t take away his pain, and you long for him to smile at you, is more difficult and more painful than you could imagine.

Thank you, Katie Mathias.

 
 
From John's Mum;
As a mother to discover your child has been diagnosed with a rare genetic disorder, your life as you know it changes.You feel very helpless as you watch your child slowly deteriorate and endure unlimited amounts of pain, withdrawl and multiple surgeries.  I became trapped in a world of curiosity and disbelief as I learned more of John's condition. This connective tissue disorder stems from an inherited faulty collegen gene from our family.  It affects strength, elasticity of the muscles, skin, joints and major organs.  It also affects the blood vessels and can result in spontaneous arterial and intestinal rupture. It also can result in Aortic dissection ond other cardiac abnormalities, such as mitral valve  prolapse. Hypermobile joints with frequent dislocations are common. The skin becomes very fragile and stretchable that can easily bruise and tear.  There is severe musculosketetal pain and fatigue, along with delayed healing.  There can be neurological and/or spinal involvement. Cerebral arterial ruptures cause altered mental states and can be mistaken for drug overdose.  As this is an invisible illness, and since it is degenerative, the only hope I have for my son is for him to find some sort of a comfort zone and to have a reasonable quality of life.  He has made the choice of getting off all narcotic medications to try and gain the ablility to spend some quality time with his wife, daughter, family and friends. I support him in every endeavor and I am asking humbly for your support. 
 
Thank you, Rita Hallewick 
 
 
From John's Mother In-law;
John entered our lives in 1991, and our daughter fell madly in love with him, they married and I gained a "son."  As a young couple they shared many adventures, travelling south to Mount Rushmore, west to the Okanagan Valley, north to the Yukon and back home again.  In 1994 they were blessed with a beautiful daugther Katie.  When she was just a toddler, John was diagnosed with Ehlers Danlos Syndrome and then began the terrifying battle of pain, immobility, losing his job and being unable to work. Sherri and Katie rallied around him providing loving comfort and support to ease this transition to the best of their abilities.  In spite of this life changing moment, John continually offered his time setting up family bbq's on Canada Day, with hamburgers, hot dogs and a fabulous firework display.  He also would offer his services to renovate, fix, repair our family homes along with setting up technical gadgets, such as tv's, surround sounds, and repairing computers.  Much of this was done in spite of "very bad days" of pain and withdrawl symptoms.  His choice to get off the narcotics is very courageous, and I offer love and support to John, Sherri and Katie during this difficult transition, and ask for your support to help him achieve his goals.
 
Thank you, Betty Attenborough
 
 
From John's best friend;
I've known John for about 10 years and I consider him to be my best friend. When I was first getting to know him I learned about his medical issues and the fentanyl patches he was on. John expressed concern that while on the patch he wasn't himself. He described that he often would see situations starting and felt like he was just witnessing the event without any control over what would happen. I understood what he was saying, but I did not really see what he meant until John began to reduce his medication. Over the months that followed I was able to meet a new John who I never had the pleasure of knowing fully before. To know someone for a decade and not know the real person because of the side effects of a medication was surprising. Right now, the withdrawal from getting off of the fentanyl patch has hit him pretty hard. He's able to hide it slightly from us and put on a happy face, but we can see what he is going through inside. This treatment will allow him to be free of this detrimental drug for good.
John has always been a very compassionate man and regularly goes above and beyond to do anything he can for anyone in need. John gladly shares anything he has. Over the years he has rescued hundreds of animals and donated to many causes. He has helped friends, family, and acquaintances with guidance, understanding, and compassion, and been the most selfless person I know. He is the most deserving person I can imagine to receive assistance towards reaching his goal, and I'm looking forward to getting to know my best friend all over again!
 
Thanks for your consideration, Rob St. John.
 
 
 
The video is from John's facebook account and the following is an explanation of the progress that he has made, created on March 15, 2013.
 
"Almost 14 years ago I put a Fentanyl patch on my body for the first time, and as of today, at 2:30 pm I AM FINALLY FREE!!!  Since that first day, I have had a Fentanyl patch attached to my body every second of every day of that entire time.  It has been a nightmarishly brutal process, one that took 7 months to complete, but it is FINALLY OVER!  I started at a dose of 25 mcg/h, and by 2008 I was at 175 mcg/h, which is two patches (100 + 75) since the maximum single patch dose ...is 100 mcg/h.  I would have been on a much higher dose if I had allowed to doctors to increase it as they wished, but I'm kind of stubborn and I resisted.  I had been trying to find a non-narcotic alternative since early 2000, and I tried numerous experimental and alternative medications and therapies, but nothing really helped.  I kept pushing my doctors to find something else, and they kept asking me to bear with them and be patient, but early last year I decided that I had had enough.  I told them that I wanted to get off of the Fentany patch, but they didn't like the idea and asked for more time.  I waited a few more months, but in August I told them that I was done with Fentanyl and narcotics in general, and that I was going to start the process when my prescription was done in about a week.  They reluctantly agreed but wanted me to go at a slow pace, as they were worried about complications.  I decided to push the pace, and a little over a week later I made the first drop from 175 mcg/h to 150 mcg/h.  I continued to drop 25 mcg/h every 30 days, with each drop being incrementally higher by percentage.  As a result, it became more and more difficult and painful as time went on.  30 days ago I dropped from 25 mcg/h to 12 mcg/h, which is more than 50%, and the biggest drop until today which was 100%.  This has been an incredibly painful and exhausting process, and I'm sure that the elation that I'm feeling will soon be replaced with as of yet unrealised amounts of pain and withdrawl, but I know that it will all be worth it in the end.  Unfortunately this isn't truly the end of the process, as I still have to get off of the long acting synthetic morphine pills that I also take.  If I follow the schedule that my doctors recommend, it will take 17 months, but I'm going to do it in 5 months.  I want to thank everyone that has sent me their love and support during this difficult time, it means more to me than you will ever know.  To my wife Sherri Mathias , our daughter Katie Mathias, my mum Marian Hallewick and my best buddy Rob St John, I want to give an EXTRA SPECIAL THANK YOU!  Thank you so much for all of the love, compassion, understanding, caring, support and ABOVE ALL - PATIENCE that you have all shown me during this horrible ordeal since I know that it has been very hard for all of you as well.  I love you all so much, and I'm sure that I could never have done this without your help!  That being said, PLEASE don't give up on me just yet!  I still have a few months of hell to go through before I will truly be free, but once it's over it will be SO AMAZING!"
story_txt:
From John’s wife;
As a wife, it has been really hard to see my husband go through the degenerative process that is Ehlers-Danlos syndrome.  We first met nearly 22 years ago, in the late summer of 1991, and we instantly fell in love.  John asked me to marry him two weeks later, and I said yes.   John was such a hard worker back then, but he already had some issues with his health.  He was on call 24/7 for his job, and he absolutely loved every minute of it.  He would work 16 hours, come home exhausted, then have to go out again in the middle of the night, but he never once complained.  When it comes to family, and people in general, John has always held fast to the ethics that his grandparents instilled in him as a child; you always help people, no matter what.  John helped anyone that was in need, and he never stopped helping people, even when he was sick.  When it came to family and friends, no matter how big or complicated the job, he would do everything that he could, to fulfill every request that he could, and he would do so without asking for, or accepting, any payment at all.  Over the years he slowly became a different person due to the constant pain and frequent injuries.  Where he was once so sweet, friendly and easy going, he was now becoming increasingly irritable, angry, and short tempered.  None of his doctors could explain what was causing all of these problems, and some questioned whether there actually were any, but that would all soon change.  When the day finally came in 1997 that John could no longer work due to his frequent injuries and the constant, unrelenting pain that he was in, we were both devastated.  John has a very specific view of what the terms husband and father mean, and without the ability to provide for his family, he felt that he was fulfilling neither.  In 1999 John was diagnosed with Ehlers-Danlos syndrome type 3, and finally the questions that we had been asking for years were beginning to be answered.  Initially it was very difficult for both of us to deal with the finality of his diagnosis.  There were major implications now with regard to his lifespan, our daughter, and his various medications, not to mention the unknown variables.  The changes in his health and his way of life have been dramatic to say the least, and his constant decline has been as evident, as it has been upsetting, to everyone around him.  He is unable to eat most foods as they upset his stomach, so he tends to eat the same things day in and day out, sometimes for years at a time.  He doesn’t sleep well at all, and he has difficulty with his memory as well as with concentrating.  Some of his joints dislocate very easily, and he once went for more than a week with a dislocated right shoulder.  He has become very adept at hiding his pain from everyone, including myself.  John doesn’t like it when people worry about him, especially those of us that love him, so he hides his pain from everyone.  Sometimes he can’t hide it, and it upsets him to the point that he apologizes to us.  Even when he is suffering from the most agonizing pain, and suffering so badly that he can no longer hide it from us, he maintains an optimism that I honestly find frustrating at times.  He has a saying, and whenever someone asks him how he’s doing, or how much pain he is in, he always tries to reassure us that he’s ok by saying; “It could always be worse”.  We have been married for 19 years, and I continue to love him more and more, each and every day that we are together.  If I could have one wish, I would wish that he could be comfortable on a daily basis, and my main goal is to try to help him live a more comfortable life.  I believe that he deserves to be able to live his life to the fullest, and right now, in large part due to the medications that he is on, that is impossible.  He has effectively lost the last 15 ½ years of his life to Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, and I do not want that to continue.
Thank you, Sherri Mathias.    

 

From John's daughter Katie;
Growing up my entire life I remember many things about my dad being sick.  Most, if not all, were hard to deal with, but some were downright unbearable.  Things such as hearing the whispers behind closed doors, the often tearful phone calls to my grandmother, and, on a few occasions, reading the "goodbye" notes that were left as my father went to the hospital for yet another surgery.  It has not only been hard on me, but it has been hard on my mother as well.  My parents always tried to put on a smile and tell me that everything was "ok", but as the years went by, and I continued to see the same, pained expression on my father’s face, it became more and more apparent that it was not "ok".  I was 3 ½ years old when the doctors diagnosed my dad with Ehlers-Danlos syndrome.  He had already lost his ability to work by then, so my mom had to go to work just to keep us afloat.  Even though I don’t remember much from those early days, I do remember the days that followed.  I remember coming home from school every night and seeing him laying on the couch drenched in sweat, and I remember wishing that there was something that I could do or some comfort that I could give to him.  I remember the countless apologies from my dad because he felt that he had failed me as a father, and to this day I know that he wishes he could have given me the life that he wanted to give me.  It pains me to see him so upset, and to see him being so hard on himself all the time.  Growing up knowing that your father is in so much pain that he can’t even get out of bed, and that no matter what you do you can’t make him feel better, you can’t take away his pain, and you long for him to smile at you, is more difficult and more painful than you could imagine.
Thank you, Katie Mathias.

 
 
From John's Mum;
As a mother to discover your child has been diagnosed with a rare genetic disorder, your life as you know it changes.You feel very helpless as you watch your child slowly deteriorate and endure unlimited amounts of pain, withdrawl and multiple surgeries.  I became trapped in a world of curiosity and disbelief as I learned more of John's condition. This connective tissue disorder stems from an inherited faulty collegen gene from our family.  It affects strength, elasticity of the muscles, skin, joints and major organs.  It also affects the blood vessels and can result in spontaneous arterial and intestinal rupture. It also can result in Aortic dissection ond other cardiac abnormalities, such as mitral valve  prolapse. Hypermobile joints with frequent dislocations are common. The skin becomes very fragile and stretchable that can easily bruise and tear.  There is severe musculosketetal pain and fatigue, along with delayed healing.  There can be neurological and/or spinal involvement. Cerebral arterial ruptures cause altered mental states and can be mistaken for drug overdose.  As this is an invisible illness, and since it is degenerative, the only hope I have for my son is for him to find some sort of a comfort zone and to have a reasonable quality of life.  He has made the choice of getting off all narcotic medications to try and gain the ablility to spend some quality time with his wife, daughter, family and friends. I support him in every endeavor and I am asking humbly for your support. 
 
Thank you, Rita Hallewick 
 
 
From John's Mother In-law;
John entered our lives in 1991, and our daughter fell madly in love with him, they married and I gained a "son."  As a young couple they shared many adventures, travelling south to Mount Rushmore, west to the Okanagan Valley, north to the Yukon and back home again.  In 1994 they were blessed with a beautiful daugther Katie.  When she was just a toddler, John was diagnosed with Ehlers Danlos Syndrome and then began the terrifying battle of pain, immobility, losing his job and being unable to work. Sherri and Katie rallied around him providing loving comfort and support to ease this transition to the best of their abilities.  In spite of this life changing moment, John continually offered his time setting up family bbq's on Canada Day, with hamburgers, hot dogs and a fabulous firework display.  He also would offer his services to renovate, fix, repair our family homes along with setting up technical gadgets, such as tv's, surround sounds, and repairing computers.  Much of this was done in spite of "very bad days" of pain and withdrawl symptoms.  His choice to get off the narcotics is very courageous, and I offer love and support to John, Sherri and Katie during this difficult transition, and ask for your support to help him achieve his goals.
 
Thank you, Betty Attenborough
 

 
From John's best friend;
I've known John for about 10 years and I consider him to be my best friend. When I was first getting to know him I learned about his medical issues and the fentanyl patches he was on. John expressed concern that while on the patch he wasn't himself. He described that he often would see situations starting and felt like he was just witnessing the event without any control over what would happen. I understood what he was saying, but I did not really see what he meant until John began to reduce his medication. Over the months that followed I was able to meet a new John who I never had the pleasure of knowing fully before. To know someone for a decade and not know the real person because of the side effects of a medication was surprising. Right now, the withdrawal from getting off of the fentanyl patch has hit him pretty hard. He's able to hide it slightly from us and put on a happy face, but we can see what he is going through inside. This treatment will allow him to be free of this detrimental drug for good.
John has always been a very compassionate man and regularly goes above and beyond to do anything he can for anyone in need. John gladly shares anything he has. Over the years he has rescued hundreds of animals and donated to many causes. He has helped friends, family, and acquaintances with guidance, understanding, and compassion, and been the most selfless person I know. He is the most deserving person I can imagine to receive assistance towards reaching his goal, and I'm looking forward to getting to know my best friend all over again!
 
Thanks for your consideration, Rob St. John.

 
 
 
The video is from John's facebook account and the following is an explanation of the progress that he has made, created on March 15, 2013.
 
"Almost 14 years ago I put a Fentanyl patch on my body for the first time, and as of today, at 2:30 pm I AM FINALLY FREE!!!  Since that first day, I have had a Fentanyl patch attached to my body every second of every day of that entire time.  It has been a nightmarishly brutal process, one that took 7 months to complete, but it is FINALLY OVER!  I started at a dose of 25 mcg/h, and by 2008 I was at 175 mcg/h, which is two patches (100 + 75) since the maximum single patch dose ...is 100 mcg/h.  I would have been on a much higher dose if I had allowed to doctors to increase it as they wished, but I'm kind of stubborn and I resisted.  I had been trying to find a non-narcotic alternative since early 2000, and I tried numerous experimental and alternative medications and therapies, but nothing really helped.  I kept pushing my doctors to find something else, and they kept asking me to bear with them and be patient, but early last year I decided that I had had enough.  I told them that I wanted to get off of the Fentany patch, but they didn't like the idea and asked for more time.  I waited a few more months, but in August I told them that I was done with Fentanyl and narcotics in general, and that I was going to start the process when my prescription was done in about a week.  They reluctantly agreed but wanted me to go at a slow pace, as they were worried about complications.  I decided to push the pace, and a little over a week later I made the first drop from 175 mcg/h to 150 mcg/h.  I continued to drop 25 mcg/h every 30 days, with each drop being incrementally higher by percentage.  As a result, it became more and more difficult and painful as time went on.  30 days ago I dropped from 25 mcg/h to 12 mcg/h, which is more than 50%, and the biggest drop until today which was 100%.  This has been an incredibly painful and exhausting process, and I'm sure that the elation that I'm feeling will soon be replaced with as of yet unrealised amounts of pain and withdrawl, but I know that it will all be worth it in the end.  Unfortunately this isn't truly the end of the process, as I still have to get off of the long acting synthetic morphine pills that I also take.  If I follow the schedule that my doctors recommend, it will take 17 months, but I'm going to do it in 5 months.  I want to thank everyone that has sent me their love and support during this difficult time, it means more to me than you will ever know.  To my wife Sherri Mathias , our daughter Katie Mathias, my mum Marian Hallewick and my best buddy Rob St John, I want to give an EXTRA SPECIAL THANK YOU!  Thank you so much for all of the love, compassion, understanding, caring, support and ABOVE ALL - PATIENCE that you have all shown me during this horrible ordeal since I know that it has been very hard for all of you as well.  I love you all so much, and I'm sure that I could never have done this without your help!  That being said, PLEASE don't give up on me just yet!  I still have a few months of hell to go through before I will truly be free, but once it's over it will be SO AMAZING!"

story:
Contact Timothy: Couragetolive@me.com 

 

THE PREMISE:

 

The premise of Indomitable is simple. The primary care physician who fired me as a patient in 1995 said something I heard echoed repeatedly over the following twelve years, “There is nothing that can be done for your pain. You need to learn to live with it.” When a physician, who is not interested in trying many options, runs out of options, “Learn to live with it" is a knee-jerk reaction. The problem I have with the phrase “learn to live with it,” is there was an answer for me, and it was a medication available long before my accident. Because of the health care system, and the federal government’s mingling, I had to fight for over a decade to find the help I deserved. I lived in constant electroshock torture the entire time. Millions of Americans are going through the same thing. The book Indomitable, and sibling inspirational speaking tour, are my way to take everything bad that has happened to me because of trauma and chronic pain, and turn it into a mechanism to help others who are living in torture break free.  

 

THE CONTRIBUTORS, Indomitable is supported by:

    • Top pain management and narcotics addiction specialists,
    • Professors of Political Science & Public Administration,
    • Primary Care Physicians,
    • Mental Health Professionals and PTSD Experts,
    • Alternative/Chinese Medicine Specialists,
    • Survivors of the Century 16 shooting tragedy in Aurora, CO, Inspirational Stories of Recovery
    • A Platinum Selling Recording Artist and Victim of Chronic Phantom Nerve Pain,
    • and many more!

 

THE FACTS: (please see works cited below for links to original works)

    • Army Surgeon General
  1. In 2010, after 12 months of research by a team of experts, the Surgeon General of the Army and commander of U.S. Army Medical Command reported, “The failure to adequately address pain in the health care system continues to result in unnecessary suffering, exacerbation of other medical conditions, and huge financial and personnel costs.”

 

    • American Pain Academy
  1. A recent market research report indicates that more than 1.5 billion people worldwide suffer from chronic pain and that approximately 3- 4.5% of the global population suffers from neuropathic pain, with incidence rate increasing in complementary to age.

 

    • The C.A.T.O. Institute
  1. Conservative estimates say that there are 30 million to 50 million sufferers of chronic pain, which is one doctor for every 6,000 pain patients. The average pain doctor has maybe 300 patients. Pain patients are very difficult to manage and require intensive attention, so there are not nearly enough pain doctors to handle the workload.

 

    • The American Association of Pain Medicine
  1. The total annual incremental cost of health care due to pain ranges from $560 billion to $635 billion (in 2010 dollars) in the United States, which combines the medical costs of pain care and the economic costs related to disability days and lost wages and productivity.
  2. More than half of all hospitalized patients experienced pain in the last days of their lives and although therapies are present to alleviate most pain for those dying of cancer, research shows that 50-75% of patients die in moderate to severe pain.
  3. An estimated 20% of American adults (42 million people) report that pain or physical discomfort disrupts their sleep a few nights a week or more.

 

 

THE NEED:

 

    • Edmonton Journal

 

  1. Article: When the hurting won't stop - How chronic physical pain drove a teen to take his life.

 

    • USA Today

 

  1. More than half of the nearly 460 Americans who lost multiple limbs to combat in Iraq and Afghanistan since 2001 suffered those wounds here in Afghanistan in just the past two and a half years. From 2001 through 2009, seven troops had triple amputations in combat and one lost all four limbs; all occurred in Iraq. Since 2010, after President Obama ordered a surge in combat against the Taliban, there have been 36 triple amputees and four quadruple amputees, all in Afghanistan, Army data shows.

 

    • Northwestern Medical School in Chicago reports on a nerve disorder so severe it's called the "suicide disease". 

 

  1. John Kerkemeyer, of Romeoville, was 22 when he was diagnosed with the disease 14 years ago. Kerkemeyer was having lunch when he first experienced pain he said must be worse than electric shock therapy.

 

 

THE BACKGROUND:

 

Depending on the source, there are 50 to 116 million Americans affected by chronic pain, and I am one of the worst cases. On the evening of April 9, 1995, three nerves were avulsed (ripped) from my spine when a half-ton truck crushed me into the side of the highway at 100 miles-per-hour. My pelvis was completely shattered, both femoral arteries severed, and bone fragments ripped apart multiple internal organs. 

No surgeon or specialist at the top in the nation Denver General Hospital thought I would survive the 45-day coma. When I survived it was hailed by many as a miracle. I never felt like a miracle; all I felt was severe pain...

Three years ago I decided to write a book, but I knew what I wrote needed to be much more than an autobiography if it was to help the millions of others who suffer from pain. I returned to college to become a better writer, learned how to research properly, and buried myself in primary research. 

The primary research and statistics I reveal in Indomitable do not reveal an easy path for the pain patient. An overwhelming majority of extremely severe chronic pain patients are never referred beyond their primary care physician who is typically not trained to treat chronic pain. I was told "learn to live with it" repeatedly for twelve years; then I met the man who slashed my pain in half within a week of meeting me. I never received any help from primary care. My fear is that many people are lose hope because they have complete faith in a physician who is unqualified to say, “There is nothing that can be done.” 

The future isn't all dark for pain patients and Indomitable is not an attack on modern medicine. I have partnered with several top scholars, experts, and medical professionals to provide viable options for pain patients in The Chronic Pain Survival Guide. Every pain patient is unique so the information in Indomitable is presented in broad strokes. I do not attempt to give medical advice, rather the book is meant to point the patient in the direction of those who can give them valuable medical advice. 

There is nothing worse than feeling horrible, losing the hope of feeling any better, and contemplating a future where each step is accompanied by severe pain. Indomitable is written in a manner to make the pain patient passionate about their recovery, and emboldened about their right avoid unnecessary suffering all day... every day. 

 

THE PROJECT LEAD:

Timothy J. Miller is a 37 year-old Cultural Anthropology major, freelance journalist and photojournalist, public speaker and poet/writer from Denver, CO. April 9, 1995, he was one of four passengers ejected from a GMC pickup truck during a high speed rollover accident. After being slammed to the ground hard enough to break bones and rupture internal organs, Timothy was then rolled over and crushed into the side of the highway by the half-ton vehicle.

Seventeen years later Timothy J. Miller is on a mission to relieve suffering in America. Chronic pain is largely uncontrolled and he understands, firsthand, the depression and hopelessness that walks hand-in-hand with severe chronic pain. There is a light at the end of the tunnel. With the book Indomitable, and related speaking tour, Timothy hopes to help our most tortured friends and family members turn away from the darkness of chronic pain, and turn into the light of quality of life. 

 

THE FUNDING:

This Indie Go Go request is for $24,999 to complete the full Indomitable manuscript, pay to have it professionally edited, prepare the manuscript for publishing including graphic and web design, travel expenses to secure contracts with contributors and conduct top priority interviews, and to finalize the Indomitable inspirational speaking tour. I have spent years buried deep in primary research and have enough to fill several books. As relationships with top pain related nonprofits, medical professionals, and mental health professionals grow and flourish, the book and speaking tour become more succinct and focused on presenting the most important information in the easiest to understand manner. Much of the prewriting is complete and the chapter structure has been refined to fit a standard word count of approximately 80,000 words. 

I am making this request now, because if I can fund this book and speaking tour before January then I will take spring semester off from college to finish the Indomitable lineup. I cannot be a successful full-time student and put my everything into this book and public speaking tour. I still have six to 10 years of college left as I am pursuing several doctorates

I am ready. Countless college professors and top industry professionals support the book. All I need is your support and I can begin the journey of bringing an indomitable spirit and inspirational  story to those who need it most. I cannot do it without your help! With this full funding request and six months I can have a manuscript professionally edited and ready to present to a major publisher and a speaking tour ready to start booking engagements.

 

 

THE SUPPORTERS:

Level 1 Supporter

$1 - $49: For a donation in this range you receive my promise to put my everything into Indomitable to produce a no nonsense and easy to understand survival guide for the chronic pain patient. 

Level 2 Supporter

$50 - $249: Donations in this range receive the same promise above, and also special recognition in a "Special Thanks" section of the book Indomitable.

Level 3 Supporter

$250 - $999: Level 3 donors receive the benefits of Level 1 & 2 donors, and will be represented with a banner or logo display at Indomitable speaking engagements. Priority and visibility will be based on size of Level 3 donation vs. other Level 3 donors. 

Level 4 Supporter

$1,000 plus: Level 4 donors receive the benefits of a level 1 - 3 donor, and also receive the opportunity to to become part of the Indomitable team and take part in the shaping of the Indomitable book and inspirational speaking tour. Level 4 donors will also have their logo printed on the back cover of all Indomitable printings, including later editions, providing the donor remains in business.

 

THE BOOK COVER:

CHECK BACK AFTER THANKSGIVING FOR COVER ART CONCEPTS

 

THE POETRY: Every chapter will be summarized with a poem by Timothy J. Miller. This is a poem from the COMA chapter. 

People often ask me what it was like to be in a coma. They ask like it was an amazing experience similar to zip-lining the grand canyon and their intrigue and excitement levels increase immediately as they ask. Questions about seeing "the light" and other religious references are very common. I decided to put one of those 45 comatose days into a poem so I never have to tell the story or revisit the memories again. It has been seventeen years and far time I shed myself of that pain. The poem represents the last day of the coma, each previous day was similar... repetitive, and those feelings still haunt me seventeen years later. There was no white light, a morphine allergy had a lot to do with that, but I only experienced darkness and fear for a month and a half. What follows is one of those days.

 

TITLE: Translation - S.O.S.

 

[Begin Transmission]

 

Morphine streams gritty film grain reality feeds;

Shadows shift, the symphony of silence is terrifying.

Obfuscated observations spinning fast;

Sensorium stifled and starved, diet of the abyss, force-fed confusion.

Repressed reactions to salivating screams in the dark dead distance,

Sickness of mind stalking unseen, fidgeting nervously;

Overstimulated hellhounds anticipating attack.

Onto my scent.

 

Pretending to be brave, feigning strength; fists raised... bloodied knuckles.

Horrified, aching hopelessness; playing for keeps, hide-and-seek with Pennywise.

Hollow. Cocooned in muted emotions, morphogenesis altering perception in realtime;

Evil butterfly opportunistic of a weakened state; there is no beauty in a hellish place.

Idiopathic attacks, encircled by death's most eminent fiends, hooded degenerates;

Well used sickles glisten gritty, sickly, bloody flashes of light;

Imminence whispering, saying they will tear through me.

Nearing the breaking point, stress fractures spray into spider-webbed fireworks.

Mental infrastructure faltering, concrete cracks, articulated rebar exposed.

Endless nightmare dreamscape, repetitiousness, nerves hammered like a blacksmith's tools.

Will heated white hot in a forge, pounded paper thin on the anvil;

Constricting slowly -python patience- bone crusher, the aperture reduces.

Thrown in a hole for my own protection, medicated with no discretion.

Opened up, weakened state, transfused with dreadfulness;

Anemic, nothing sacred, death raps on my mind's screen door,

Mesh sails, hapless vessel, wind picks up taunting my inability to help myself;

Filled with holes losing buoyancy, reduced to tears and broken pleads.

Apathetic suffrages, pathetic prayers boring deep, changing me,

Losing faith, close to giving up. STOP!

I am never surrendering.

 

[End Transmission]

 

Awake... in the nick of time.

"Timothy, Timothy you were in an horrible accident. You've been in a coma."

Fall back into the pillow, tension on arm restraints loosens,

Sleep for the first time in forty five days. Safe... for the moment.

 

 

THE NEXT STEP: 

Over the next few weeks I will post a chapter structure, several podcasts updating my progress with the book, and samples from the Indomitable Keynote presentation. I also have a photo essay on chronic pain that will be posted by December 1, 2012 in the updates section of my Indie Go Go funding request. 

 

THE MOST IMPORTANT PART:

Thank you! Thank you for supporting my effort to bring quality of life to the conservatively estimated 50 million sufferers of chronic pain in the United States and over a billion chronic pain victims worldwide. I hope this is the signal shot in a very long race to beat chronic pain, I would love to have you as a running partner, and remember... always be Indomitable!

THE WORKS CITED:

 

1 Eric B. Schoomaker, Lieutenant General. Pain Management Task Force - Final Report. United States Army. 01 May 2012. Web. 13 Nov. 2012. <http://www.armymedicine.army.mil/reports/Pain_Management_Task_Force.pdf>

2 American Pain Association. <http://www.painmed.org/patientcenter/facts_on_p...>

3 Global Industry Analysts, Inc. Report, January 10, 2011. <http://www.prweb.com/pdfdownload/8052240.pdf>.

4 The C.A.T.O. Institute. <http://www.cato.org/research/articles/cpr27n6b-051101.html>

5 American Academy of Pain Medicine. AAPM Facts and Figures on Pain. <http://www.painmed.org/patientcenter/facts_on_p...> 

6 Institute of Medicine Report from the Committee on Advancing Pain Research, Care, and Education: Relieving Pain in America, A Blueprint for Transforming Prevention, Care, Education and Research. The National Academies Press, 2011. <http://books.nap.edu/openbook.php?record_id=13172&page=1>.

7 A Controlled Trial to Improve Care for Seriously Ill Hospitalized Patients. <http://jama.ama-assn.org/cgi/content/abstract/274/20/1591>

8 National Sleep Foundation. <http://www.sleepfoundation.org>. Sleep in America poll. 2000.

9 Edmonton Journal. <http://www.edmontonjournal.com/news/calgary/When+hurting+stop/7564230/story.html>

10 USA Today  - <http://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation/2012/11/14/medics-save-troops-with-horrific-injuries/1705859/>

11 http://news.medill.northwestern.edu/chicago/news.aspx?id=79817

THE BACKGROUND:
 
Depending on the source, there are 50 to 116 million Americans affected by chronic pain, and I am one of the worst cases. On the evening of April 9, 1995, three nerves were avulsed (ripped) from my spine when a half-ton truck crushed me into the side of the highway at 100 miles-per-hour. My pelvis was completely shattered, both femoral arteries severed, and bone fragments ripped apart multiple internal organs. 
No surgeon or specialist at the top in the nation Denver General Hospital thought I would survive the 45-day coma. When I survived it was hailed by many as a miracle. I never felt like a miracle; all I felt was severe pain...
Three years ago I decided to write a book, but I knew what I wrote needed to be much more than an autobiography if it was to help the millions of others who suffer from pain. I returned to college to become a better writer, learned how to research properly, and buried myself in primary research. 
The primary research and statistics I reveal in Indomitable do not reveal an easy path for the pain patient. An overwhelming majority of extremely severe chronic pain patients are never referred beyond their primary care physician who is typically not trained to treat chronic pain. I was told "learn to live with it" repeatedly for twelve years; then I met the man who slashed my pain in half within a week of meeting me. I never received any help from primary care. My fear is that many people are lose hope because they have complete faith in a physician who is unqualified to say, “There is nothing that can be done.” 
The future isn't all dark for pain patients and Indomitable is not an attack on modern medicine. I have partnered with several top scholars, experts, and medical professionals to provide viable options for pain patients in The Chronic Pain Survival Guide. Every pain patient is unique so the information in Indomitable is presented in broad strokes. I do not attempt to give medical advice, rather the book is meant to point the patient in the direction of those who can give them valuable medical advice. 
There is nothing worse than feeling horrible, losing the hope of feeling any better, and contemplating a future where each step is accompanied by severe pain. Indomitable is written in a manner to make the pain patient passionate about their recovery, and emboldened about their right avoid unnecessary suffering all day... every day. 
 
THE PROJECT LEAD:
Timothy J. Miller is a 37 year-old Cultural Anthropology major, freelance journalist and photojournalist, public speaker and poet/writer from Denver, CO. April 9, 1995, he was one of four passengers ejected from a GMC pickup truck during a high speed rollover accident. After being slammed to the ground hard enough to break bones and rupture internal organs, Timothy was then rolled over and crushed into the side of the highway by the half-ton vehicle.
Seventeen years later Timothy J. Miller is on a mission to relieve suffering in America. Chronic pain is largely uncontrolled and he understands, firsthand, the depression and hopelessness that walks hand-in-hand with severe chronic pain. There is a light at the end of the tunnel. With the book Indomitable, and related speaking tour, Timothy hopes to help our most tortured friends and family members turn away from the darkness of chronic pain, and turn into the light of quality of life. 
 
THE FUNDING:
This Indie Go Go request is for $24,999 to complete the full Indomitable manuscript, pay to have it professionally edited, prepare the manuscript for publishing including graphic and web design, travel expenses to secure contracts with contributors and conduct top priority interviews, and to finalize the Indomitable inspirational speaking tour. I have spent years buried deep in primary research and have enough to fill several books. As relationships with top pain related nonprofits, medical professionals, and mental health professionals grow and flourish, the book and speaking tour become more succinct and focused on presenting the most important information in the easiest to understand manner. Much of the prewriting is complete and the chapter structure has been refined to fit a standard word count of approximately 80,000 words. 
I am making this request now, because if I can fund this book and speaking tour before January then I will take spring semester off from college to finish the Indomitable lineup. I cannot be a successful full-time student and put my everything into this book and public speaking tour. I still have six to 10 years of college left as I am pursuing several doctorates
I am ready. Countless college professors and top industry professionals support the book. All I need is your support and I can begin the journey of bringing an indomitable spirit and inspirational  story to those who need it most. I cannot do it without your help! With this full funding request and six months I can have a manuscript professionally edited and ready to present to a major publisher and a speaking tour ready to start booking engagements.
 
 
THE SUPPORTERS:
Level 1 Supporter
$1 - $49: For a donation in this range you receive my promise to put my everything into Indomitable to produce a no nonsense and easy to understand survival guide for the chronic pain patient. 
Level 2 Supporter
$50 - $249: Donations in this range receive the same promise above, and also special recognition in a "Special Thanks" section of the book Indomitable.
Level 3 Supporter
$250 - $999: Level 3 donors receive the benefits of Level 1 & 2 donors, and will be represented with a banner or logo display at Indomitable speaking engagements. Priority and visibility will be based on size of Level 3 donation vs. other Level 3 donors. 
Level 4 Supporter
$1,000 plus: Level 4 donors receive the benefits of a level 1 - 3 donor, and also receive the opportunity to to become part of the Indomitable team and take part in the shaping of the Indomitable book and inspirational speaking tour. Level 4 donors will also have their logo printed on the back cover of all Indomitable printings, including later editions, providing the donor remains in business.
 
THE BOOK COVER:
CHECK BACK AFTER THANKSGIVING FOR COVER ART CONCEPTS
 
THE POETRY: Every chapter will be summarized with a poem by Timothy J. Miller. This is a poem from the COMA chapter. 
People often ask me what it was like to be in a coma. They ask like it was an amazing experience similar to zip-lining the grand canyon and their intrigue and excitement levels increase immediately as they ask. Questions about seeing "the light" and other religious references are very common. I decided to put one of those 45 comatose days into a poem so I never have to tell the story or revisit the memories again. It has been seventeen years and far time I shed myself of that pain. The poem represents the last day of the coma, each previous day was similar... repetitive, and those feelings still haunt me seventeen years later. There was no white light, a morphine allergy had a lot to do with that, but I only experienced darkness and fear for a month and a half. What follows is one of those days.
 
TITLE: Translation - S.O.S.
 
[Begin Transmission]
 
Morphine streams gritty film grain reality feeds;
Shadows shift, the symphony of silence is terrifying.
Obfuscated observations spinning fast;
Sensorium stifled and starved, diet of the abyss, force-fed confusion.
Repressed reactions to salivating screams in the dark dead distance,
Sickness of mind stalking unseen, fidgeting nervously;
Overstimulated hellhounds anticipating attack.
Onto my scent.
 
Pretending to be brave, feigning strength; fists raised... bloodied knuckles.
Horrified, aching hopelessness; playing for keeps, hide-and-seek with Pennywise.
Hollow. Cocooned in muted emotions, morphogenesis altering perception in realtime;
Evil butterfly opportunistic of a weakened state; there is no beauty in a hellish place.
Idiopathic attacks, encircled by death's most eminent fiends, hooded degenerates;
Well used sickles glisten gritty, sickly, bloody flashes of light;
Imminence whispering, saying they will tear through me.
Nearing the breaking point, stress fractures spray into spider-webbed fireworks.
Mental infrastructure faltering, concrete cracks, articulated rebar exposed.
Endless nightmare dreamscape, repetitiousness, nerves hammered like a blacksmith's tools.
Will heated white hot in a forge, pounded paper thin on the anvil;
Constricting slowly -python patience- bone crusher, the aperture reduces.
Thrown in a hole for my own protection, medicated with no discretion.
Opened up, weakened state, transfused with dreadfulness;
Anemic, nothing sacred, death raps on my mind's screen door,
Mesh sails, hapless vessel, wind picks up taunting my inability to help myself;
Filled with holes losing buoyancy, reduced to tears and broken pleads.
Apathetic suffrages, pathetic prayers boring deep, changing me,
Losing faith, close to giving up. STOP!
I am never surrendering.
 
[End Transmission]
 
Awake... in the nick of time.
"Timothy, Timothy you were in an horrible accident. You've been in a coma."
Fall back into the pillow, tension on arm restraints loosens,
Sleep for the first time in forty five days. Safe... for the moment.
 
 
THE NEXT STEP: 
Over the next few weeks I will post a chapter structure, several podcasts updating my progress with the book, and samples from the Indomitable Keynote presentation. I also have a photo essay on chronic pain that will be posted by December 1, 2012 in the updates section of my Indie Go Go funding request. 
 
THE MOST IMPORTANT PART:
Thank you! Thank you for supporting my effort to bring quality of life to the conservatively estimated 50 million sufferers of chronic pain in the United States and over a billion chronic pain victims worldwide. I hope this is the signal shot in a very long race to beat chronic pain, I would love to have you as a running partner, and remember... always be Indomitable!
THE WORKS CITED:
 
1 Eric B. Schoomaker, Lieutenant General. Pain Management Task Force - Final Report. United States Army. 01 May 2012. Web. 13 Nov. 2012. <http://www.armymedicine.army.mil/reports/Pain_Management_Task_Force.pdf>
2 American Pain Association. <http://www.painmed.org/patientcenter/facts_on_p...>
3 Global Industry Analysts, Inc. Report, January 10, 2011. <http://www.prweb.com/pdfdownload/8052240.pdf>.
4 The C.A.T.O. Institute. <http://www.cato.org/research/articles/cpr27n6b-051101.html>
5 American Academy of Pain Medicine. AAPM Facts and Figures on Pain. <http://www.painmed.org/patientcenter/facts_on_p...> 
6 Institute of Medicine Report from the Committee on Advancing Pain Research, Care, and Education: Relieving Pain in America, A Blueprint for Transforming Prevention, Care, Education and Research. The National Academies Press, 2011. <http://books.nap.edu/openbook.php?record_id=13172&page=1>.
7 A Controlled Trial to Improve Care for Seriously Ill Hospitalized Patients. <http://jama.ama-assn.org/cgi/content/abstract/274/20/1591>
8 National Sleep Foundation. <http://www.sleepfoundation.org>. Sleep in America poll. 2000.
9 Edmonton Journal. <http://www.edmontonjournal.com/news/calgary/When+hurting+stop/7564230/story.html>
10 USA Today  - <http://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation/2012/11/14/medics-save-troops-with-horrific-injuries/1705859/>
11 http://news.medill.northwestern.edu/chicago/news.aspx?id=79817

story:
I am a single mother with three children. My son Corey and I are disabled. He is very ill with a connective tissue disorder called EDS, and has had a pacemaker for 5 years now. He was born without his right ear, and is blind on his left side. They first thought he had Goldenhar Syndrome, and Marfans at another time, but at this point they are saying EDS and possibly has more than one syndrome. He blacks out on average 3-5 times a day, it doesn't matter what he is doing at the time, and it is currently unknown why he is doing this. He hurts alll the time in his joints and can dislocate a hip just rolling over in his sleep. He received the Pacemaker because his heart rate was extremely low, 3o to 40 beats per minute, so they gave him the pacemaker, and it was so nice to see color in his face again. But now his heart races at times to almost 300 beats per minute at times for no apparent reason. Needless to say, it is very scary.

Recently my only transportation broke down on the highway. After having it towed and getting an estimate at the auto shop, I was told it was the transmission and that it would cost a little over 1800.00 to have a rebuilt one bought and installed.

I have absolutely no way of coming up with that kind of money on my income and really, really need help. Corey makes numerous trips to his Cardiologist, Geneticist,and Primary care Physician. I cannot be without my van or a car of somekind to get to and from his appointments

I have tried all other options.

I recently was told about this site, and I hope and pray that someone can help me.

Sheryl B.

story:
I am in ugent need of a Double Lung Transplant.  I am in the end  stages of Emphyzema and have been told that I have a life expectancy of less than one year without the transplant.

I live in Calgary Alberta, and the transplants take place in Edmonton at the University Hospital.  I have been inflicted with this disease since1991 and have been managing up to now.  One requirement for transplantation is who ever is the sickest get the surgury the soonest.  I have been told by the Doctors that I now have a life expectancy of less than one year.  I am required to temporarily relocate to Edmonton for the six week pre transplant physio program and then another three to six monts post surgury.  I am responsible for all expenses with the exception of the Medical Proceedure.  The hospital also requires that I have a full time support person with me at all times during these periods.

After the transplant, I am hoping to return to a somewhat active life.  I am the father of two sons and the grandfather of five wonderful little children.  I look forward to the day when I can have activities with them without worrying about ending up in distress.

Everyone can help me in the campaign simply by signing your donor card.  A donation to help me with the costs would also make this possible for me.  Any amount that you can donate will be very helpful and appreciated.If the world had more visibility and campaigns to encourage healthy people to donate their organs after their life expires, Hundreds of people such as myself would not have to wait for these transplants.

story:
AS SEEN ON!!

"Could be the MOST VERSATILE" workout gadget yet!"          (Click Logo to go to Article)

.

.

"The Swiss-Army Knife of Ab Rollers"  Says the LA Times      (Click Name to go to Article)

.

.

.

.

Why do you Need The Spyder 360?

If you are like many people, your waist line has increased over the years and you may have back pain. Increasing your core strength will have a positive impact on your physical and mental well being. The Spyder 360™ is the solution to get you the results you want, reduce/eliminate your back pain, and end the boredom that comes with sit-ups and crunches.

.

(Rendering Shown Above)

.

Benefits of using The Spyder 360™

  • Easy to use and not as scary as the name implies!
  • There are dozens of effective core exercises that can be performed with the Spyders.
  • Increased core strength reduces the likelihood of back injuries.
  • Strengthen your entire core, from your mid to lower back, your obliques, and your abs.
  • You can get a full body workout with The Spyder 360™.

.

(17th Generation Prototype Shown Above)

.

Who is the Inventor?

The inventors name is Jonathan Smith. He is an Industrial Designer who invented the Spyders when his Physical Therapist told him he needed to workout everyday to recover from an injury.

.

He developed the idea as he interviewed over 100 people from all walks of life. He didn't leave anyone out as he sought to develop a fun way to workout and strengthen his entire body.

The solution he developed can be used on any surface for upper body, core, and lower body training.

.

(17th Generation Prototype Shown Above)

.

What We Need & What You Get

We need to sell out of our first order which arrives around November 28th so that we can place a second order before the new year. You get an amazing core/full body trainer at a reduced price!

.

(Production Sample Shown Above)

.

The Spyder 360™ will come in two trim levels

.

1. Basic: 2 Spyder 360's with a Thick knee pad and an exercise guide. (Digital Guide Also!)

.

.

.

2. Trainer: Builds on the Basic level by adding 2 Resistance Bands, A Door Anchor, 2 Wrist/Ankle Straps, and 2 Handles to use with your Resistance Bands.

.

.

The Impact of your support!

Purchasing my product is the greatest compliment. Even if you buy them as a gift for your spouse or club! Sharing my product with your friends will increase its visibility and is a great alternative to purchasing.

.

(Production Sample Shown Above)

.

Risks & Challenges

The risks are all on my shoulders. I have covered the tooling costs, managed through the production issues, and now I need to increase awareness of my product.

.

(The Spyder 360's work on ALL of the surfaces above)

.

Other Ways You Can Help!

Share my campaign with your friends! Want to become an affiliate? Contact me and let me know how you can support my product launch. ReferralProgram@TheSpyder360.com

story:
Short Summary

Contributors fund ideas they can be passionate about and to people they trust. Here are some things to do in this section:

  • Introduce yourself and your background.
  • Briefly describe your campaign and why it's important to you.
  • Express the magnitude of what contributors will help you achieve.

Remember, keep it concise, yet personal. Ask yourself: if someone stopped reading here would they be ready to make a contribution?

What We Need & What You Get

Break it down for folks in more detail:

  • Explain how much funding you need and where it's going. Be transparent and specific-people need to trust you to want to fund you.
  • Tell people about your unique perks. Get them excited!
  • Describe where the funds go if you don't reach your entire goal.

The Impact

Feel free to explain more about your campaign and let people know how the difference their contribution will make:

  • Explain why your project is valuable to the contributor and to the world.
  • Point out your successful track record with projects like this (if you have one).
  • Make it real for people and build trust.

Risks & Challenges

People value your transparency. Be open and stand out by providing insight into the risks and obstacles you may face on the way to achieving your goal.

  • Share what qualifies you to overcome these hurdles.
  • Describe your plan for solving these challenges.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about your campaign.
  • Remind them to use the Indiegogo share tools!

And that's all there is to it.
